title: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid
subTitle: Ford tosses down the hybrid gauntlet with its new model, which gets 47 miles per gallon both in town and on the highway.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid
metaTitle: 2013 Ford C-Max
metaDescription: 2013 ford c-max hybrid buyer's guide

pageElements.text: Hybrids are settling into the mainstream. The proof comes from Ford’s all-new C-Max Hybrid and Energi. The compact car is cute in the current Ford style, with wedgy shaping and a toothy grille, but its main selling point is fuel economy. It is rated at 47 mpg both in town and on the highway—which Ford hastens to point out is 7 mpg better than the Toyota Prius v’s highway numbers. The C-Max has a lithium-ion battery that recharges when the gasoline engine is in use; plus, there’s regenerative braking—recycling at its least onerous—which recaptures up to 95 percent of the energy used in braking and uses it to recharge the battery. The C-Max is not only efficient; it also responds to the eco-conscious aesthetic by using a greenery theme in its Smartgauge display, which displays more leaves and vines as a “visual reward” when a driver is more efficient in his or her driving habits. The C-Max’s popular price, starting just over $25,000—lower than its closest rival, the Toyota Prius, and some $10,000 cheaper than the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf—will help it win fans, as will its uncontroversial styling. The fact that you can drive the plug-in Energi at speeds up to 85 mph on electrical power alone should electrify the highway commuter crowd. But the number-one drawing card will be its efficiency in a time of insecure gasoline prices.

Competitors:
1.	Toyota Prius v
2.	Toyota Prius III


Cool Tech items
1. Smartgauge display shows a leafy vine that gets lusher the more efficiently the car is driven
2. Regenerative braking and Brake Coach to help get the most out of it
3. ECO Cruise highway cruise control technology

Looks:
1. In-floor storage in second row


New for 2013 
1. All-new model


Fun-O-Meter: 5

title: Automatic Stop/Start Technology
subTitle: Saving fuel in a car near you
promoTeaserSmall: Saving fuel and saving you money while leaving the fun where it belongs.
promoTeaser: Saving fuel and saving you money while leaving the fun where it belongs.
metaTitle: Automatic Stop/Start Technology - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Automatic Stop/Start Technology : Learn more about this fuel-saving technology, which is becoming more popular in mainstream cars, at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: With fuel economy standards steadily increasing (the latest regulations will require fleets to average 54.5 mpg by 2025), automakers are introducing fuel-saving gadgets wherever they can. One technology, already widely available in Europe, has started making its way to U.S. shores.

image.caption: Audi start/stop technology can be clearly seen when active.

pageElements.text: Start/stop systems, which allow engines to turn off while cars are stopped at red lights, aim to be an unobtrusive way to increase efficiency. It’s hard to argue with the logic. As an Audi ad campaign points out, turning off the engine while stopped is similar to turning off the lights when you leave a room. With the car stopped and the gearshift in neutral, a light on the dash will illuminate to let drivers know the technology is active. As soon as the clutch is depressed, the engine quickly turns back on again and normal driving resumes. This feature won’t earn you hybrid mileage, but for buyers looking for performance automobiles with a conscience, it is certainly a start.

Audi brought start/stop technology to the United States in 2009 and has since expanded its availability to include the A7, A8, Q5, and Q7. BMW offers the technology in all 1 and 3 Series models equipped with a four-cylinder engine and a manual transmission. Ford began introducing Auto Start-Stop to the 2013 Fusion with EcoBoost engine as a $295 option, granting access at a more affordable price point.

Taking the idea one step further, GM has introduced eAssist with the Buick LaCrosse and Regal and the Chevrolet Malibu Eco. You won’t hear GM say it in ads, but the technology turns cars into what is referred to as a “mild hybrid.” A battery motor takes over when the car is stopped, then returns power almost seamlessly to the traditional engine once the car has started rolling. GM's eAssist can also lend a little extra power when drivers demand heavy acceleration. Compared with a full hybrid, the fuel savings are modest, but GM hopes that it will be able to spread the versatile technology easily throughout its fleet. Full hybrids, on the other hand, typically require specialized engineering to maintain the car’s balance and drivability.

The actual fuel savings from these technologies can differ, depending on whom you ask and how you measure it, but even if you don’t notice a huge difference at the pump, these options may help you sleep easier, knowing that your daily drive melted a little less of the polar ice caps than everyone else’s.

title: Designing Women from Day One
subTitle: Women have had a hand in auto design from its earliest days.
promoTeaserSmall: Designing Women from Day One: You can go all the way back to the early 20th century, and there were women involved in car design.
promoTeaser: Designing Women from Day One: You can go all the way back to the early 20th century, and there were women involved in car design.
metaTitle: Designing Women from Day One, from JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Designing Women from Day One. Learn about how women have played a role in car design for more than a century but still haven't broken through the glass ceiling.

pageElements.text: Women have had a hand in auto design from way back in the earliest days of motoring.

Among the earliest known female creators of cars were Margaret E. Knight, an engineer, and her niece, Beatrice Davidson. Their K-D automobile made its debut in Brookline, Massachusetts, in 1912, according to the book A Century of Automotive Style: 100 Years of American Car Design. Unfortunately, that car wasn’t around for very long.

Miriam W. Hubbard, a banker’s daughter from Philadelphia, inspired the 1916-19 Biddle roadster. Hubbard stipulated that she wanted a sport roadster that looked like it was "going 60 mph standing still." Positively vertiginous! It had portholes in the hood, wire-spoked wheels, and V-shaped headlights, but no running boards.

Betty Thatcher is believed to be the first female designer to be hired by an automaker full time. She worked for Hudson in 1939 and designed the 1941 Hudson instrument panel and a bit of the model’s external trim.

General Motors' legendary design chief Harley Earl began bringing women aboard his design team in 1943, dubbing them his Damsels of Design. That may not be a flattering name in hindsight, but for the time, it was revolutionary enough. They worked on interiors, instrument panels, steering wheels,  and seat trim.

Yes, that was seventy long years ago, and nobody is calling the legion of professional women in the auto industry "damsels" these days--but still, here in 2012, not one major global automaker has tapped a woman to be its chief designer.

title: 2013 Ford E-Series
subTitle: Old-school full-size van just keeps rolling along.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford E-Series
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford E-Series
metaTitle: 2013 Ford E-Series -- Buyer's Guide -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Ford E-Series Truck in the Buyer's Guide at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Ford has been making its E-Series full-size van for more than three decades, and there’s a reason for that. Although the big box may not boast up-to-the-minute looks, it’s as stalwart a work companion as ever. The E-Series comes in a plethora of types, similar to the F-Series truck lineup. E-150, E-250 Super Duty, and E-350 Super Duty versions are available in both standard and extended lengths and in both wagon (passenger vehicle) and van (work truck) versions. In wagon form, there are side windows, while the van version’s sides are an unbroken expanse of sheet metal other than the front-seat side windows. Even though the E-Series has been around forever, there are modern conveniences including anti-lock brakes, a navigation system with 6.5-inch touchscreen, and Ford’s SYNC hands-free telematics system. The Crew Chief system is an option that helps commercial users manage a fleet of vehicles and the related data such as fuel usage and maintenance records. There’s nothing lyrical about an E-Series, unless you have a whole lot of stuff to cart around, in which case its capaciousness could just be music to your ears.

Competitors:
1.	Chevrolet Express
2.	GMC Savana

Cool Tech items 
1. Touchscreen display

Looks 
1. 178-degree opening rear cargo doors
Fun-O-Meter 2

title: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right?
promoTitle: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right?
promoTeaserSmall: First-time mom faces the infant car seat challenge--and prevails.
promoTeaser: First-time mom faces the infant car seat challenge--and prevails.
metaTitle: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right? Jean Knows Cars contributor and first-time mom learns how to buy and install an infant car seat. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: You might think shopping for a car seat would be easy for an automotive writer, but I assure you, it's not.

There are more than 100 models of car seats on the market, and they more or less all do the same thing. Pre-pregnancy, I probably would have just eyeballed a product and picked the model with the best balance of attractive packaging and price. However, something about expecting a child for the first time makes even so-called experts second-guess their instincts and decision-making skills and question every purchase.

Adding to the pressure was the assurance from another expectant mom in my childbirth class that this was one of the most important decisions I would be making for my child. The message is clear: choose the wrong car seat, and my baby could die.

Google, which theoretically should make researching easier, actually makes things worse. Search strings became my new forte, and they give me powerful new analytical skills, which I seem to use only when it comes to selecting baby gear. Complicated Excel spreadsheets with charts and rating systems were drafted. Anonymous questions were posted on BabyCenter.com, and e-mails were sent to product manufacturers. Perhaps too much weight and deference was given to reviewers with eyebrow-raising names like "Ms_MeowMeow."

Despite coming into the process with a better-than-average understanding of where to look for information, online shopping was a failure. I couldn't manage the dozen or so windows crowding my tiny laptop screen while cross-checking model numbers with "professional" reviews from bloggers and parenting sites, and then verifying with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration if it had been recalled or not. With my due date fast approaching, I shut my computer and headed over to the local baby mart.
But it didn’t get any easier.

I was confronted with a wall of choices. Each bulbous seat was clothed in epileptic-fit-inducing hot pink and giraffe-printed fabrics, each competing to out-bulk, out-plasticize, and out-bling the next. The minimalist in me (read: cheapskate) flirted with the idea of getting an all-in-one car seat that would take my soon-to-be-born daughter from birth to toddlerhood. But that idea was nixed by the salesperson, who swore I wouldn’t want to wake a napping baby to move her from the stroller to the car seat every time.
"Go with the infant seat," she insisted.

That meant choosing a base with a car seat that could be detached and carried by its handle into the house or attached to a stroller. The kicker was that the car seat would work for six months at most before I'd have to repeat the agonizing process of finding yet another car seat when my daughter exceeds the twenty-two or thirty-pound weight limit most infant seats provide.
It also turns out that choosing a car seat directly influences the stroller you get, forcing you to make two important decisions at once. But which do you pick first? The car seat or the stroller?

Luckily, fate decided for me. I jumped on a promotion that offered a free car seat with a purchase of a Britax B-Ready stroller, which I was already eyeing. There were two Britax car seats available, but the Chaperone was the bigger, more expensive option touting something called "recoil protection." I didn’t know what that was, but I was positive my newborn would need it.
Online reviews mentioned that the Chaperone was significantly longer than the B-Safe, which made me hesitate on the "add to cart" button.
"Get the bigger one," insisted my husband, clearly looking just to maximize the benefit of the free promotion.

But bigger wasn’t better when it came to trying to fit it into our 2008 Subaru Outback. As the online reviewer warned, it didn’t fit our mid-size car. The only way it would sit on the bench is if both front seats were adjusted all the way forward, which would definitely be safe for our child because we wouldn’t be able to fit in the car or drive anywhere.
Back the Chaperone went to Amazon, with return shipping fees eating into our promotional savings. A few days later, the smaller, cheaper B-Safe arrived.

And the second one didn’t seem to fit, either. While technically we could  squeeze it in the middle seat of the second row, we struggled to get the seatbelt tight enough. Tension seemed to come solely from the front driver and passenger seats pressing tight against the car seat, pinning it in place. Was this normal? Were we doing this right?
 
Having bought a B-Ready stroller, I was more or less stuck with this car seat, since Britax strollers only accommodate Britax car seats. So rather than turn to Google, I dialed up the local Car Seat Lady for validation.

Sue Emery is a certified child passenger safety technician, who has spent the past twenty years teaching parents in the Seattle area how to buy and properly install car seats in their vehicles. She reassured me that I didn’t make a huge mistake
"Every car seat on the market is a perfect car seat," Emery said, effectively making the all-nighter I pulled on Consumer Reports a waste of time. "But not every car seat fits every car."
Of this, I was painfully aware.
She continued, "Even if the car seat technically fits the car, it may not fit it with the driver and front passenger in it."

Since car seats are regulated and car companies independently crash test their car seats, a parent should feel confident that it will protect her child in a crash – as long as it’s installed correctly. But nine times out of ten, it’s not. This means parents should be shopping for car seat by size and fit, not by price, color, or stroller compatibility, as I did.
Apparently, the time to consult the car seat lady is before you make your purchase.

Within twenty minutes of her free consultation in the parking lot at my apartment, she taught me how to adjust the base so it fit on the bench seat and install the car seat with room for my husband and me to still fit comfortably in the front row. And I only broke two nails in the process.

Just as important were her recommendations for convertible seats that would fit my car when my daughter outgrew her infant carrier seat, which will cut my shopping time down to nothing. But next on my list is picking out the best car seat mirror so I can keep an eye on my little munchkin while I’m behind the wheel. Back to Google, for another round of overanalyzing.

images.caption: Freshly purchased car seat, ready to install.
Owner's manual is a good place to start.
The base goes in first.
Attaching it securely is the most important step.
Now I can add the removable part, where my daughter will ride.
And I'm ready!

title: 2013 Acura RL
subTitle: The RL is an old lion on its way out.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Acura RL
promoTeaser: 2013 Acura RL
metaTitle: 2013 Acura RL Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura RL Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The RL sports the same 3.7-liter V-6 engine as Acura’s TL, with plenty of power for a sedan, and the same all-wheel-drive system helps them around corners. The RL is clearly the more sedate of the two and draws in older buyers with its cushy interior. More spacious than any other Acura sedan, the RL has room for passengers to stretch out. It benefits from a sleek looking dash and information display, although the navigation system itself could use an update. Smooth leather seats come standard, as do keyless entry and a USB port and auxiliary jack for MP3 players. Change is in the air for the RL, however. After a long history as Acura’s respectable, refined sedan, the RL will become the 2014 RLX, for sale in early 2013. The new model will be bigger and heavier, and will come in a “sport hybrid” model, which Acura expects to achieve 30 mpg – a huge improvement over the current model’s 24 mpg on the highway. The RL provides more than enough comfort and drivability for its nearly $50,000 price point, but it could use a touch more excitement, which is probably exactly what the RLX will have in store.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. BMW 5 Series
2. Lincoln MKS
3. Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Cool Tech:

2. XM radio with USB and auxiliary jack.

Looks:

2. Illuminated exterior door handles.

2. 2014 RLX will be a complete redesign.

title: Teardrop Campers
subTitle: Take your good taste on a road trip!
promoTeaserSmall: These are the little gems of the highway: vintage style in tiny packages that you can go camping in.
promoTeaser: These are the little gems of the highway: vintage style in tiny packages that you can go camping in.
metaTitle: Teardrop Campers: Small Is Beautiful - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Teardrop campers: Small Is Beautiful. Teardrops are tiny gems of construction that you can make yourself, rent, or buy, then tow behind even a small car. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Have you ever heard of a teardrop trailer? One look at one, and you'll understand where they got the name. They're small, adorable, and still available to buy today.

But they have a long history. Teardrop trailers enjoyed their first success as the United States was recovering from the Great Depression, a time when having a car with a trailer meant mobility and freedom. Before there was airfare for the masses, but after the affinity for comfort was ingrained in the national psyche, these little charmers ruled the road for several decades.

Do-it-yourself plans once graced the pages of lifestyle magazines, and you can still buy trailer plans for around $20 (right). Add parts, and the whole project will set you back about $700. While campers flourished, the U.S. highway system expanded, and road trips became part of the American experience. Today, with high gas prices causing buyers to think twice before buying a Winnebago and a stalled economy putting the kibosh on luxury vacations, teardrop campers have enjoyed a recent resurgence in popularity.

Where Can You Get One?

A teardrop camper is typically small and aerodynamic, with a double bed in the cabin and a camp kitchen hidden in a hatchback-like rear storage area. Many are light enough to be towed behind any car you care to hitch them to. MiniTears specializes in custom-built trailers for Mini Coopers, and the website of manufacturer Little Guy features a picture of a tiny trailer being pulled behind ultracompact cars. And no wonder: the Little Guy Rascal (right) boasts diminutive interior measurements of 37.5 inches high, 44.5 inches wide, and 88 inches long.

Trailers can cost about $10,000 to $12,000 new or a few thousand dollars less when used, but they can also cost much more. For example, a beautifully crafted Custom Teardrop Camping Trailer from outdoor outfitter Orvis (right) comes with a sapele and mahogany body, a double bed, and a freshwater tank and faucet, priced at $29,995. If you can’t afford to spend tens of thousands on something without a motor, many dealers will rent the campers at rates that average $300 a week: try Vacations in a Can in California, or Hitch and Go Adventures in Texas, or Google "teardrop camper rental" for one nearer you. But if you want to maximize your retro street cred, find a vintage teardrop from the movement’s post-Depression-era heyday, hitch it behind a classic Chevrolet, and hit the open road.

Orvis Custom Teardrop Camping Trailer, inside.
Orvis Custom Teardrop Camping Trailer has a sapele and mahogany body.
Little Guy Rascal Teardrop trailer.

title: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations
promoTitle: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations
promoTeaserSmall: Ford's Sync Destination is the smart way to get where you need to go in your Fiesta.
promoTeaser: Ford's Sync Destination is the smart way to get where you need to go in your Fiesta.
metaTitle: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations: Learn more about the Ford Fiesta Sync services and Ford's Sync Destinations app at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: A lot of navigation apps will tell you how long it’s going to take to get where you’re going, but Ford’s Sync Destinations app  can tell you how long it will take if you leave a couple of hours from now. When you opt for Sync, Ford’s voice-control platform, you’ll get Sync Services free for three years. You can use Sync Services to get turn-by-turn directions in the car, and you also get access one of the more clever travel and traffic mobile apps on the market for free.

Powered by Inrix, Sync Destinations uses historical traffic data and takes into account local events, weather, and sporting events to help you figure out the best time to leave for your destination. From the contact list on your iPhone or Android device, you can enter up to 25 destinations or search within the app for a business listing. The app has a “Send to Sync” button that queues up turn-by-turn directions for you to download when you start the car, or you can use AppLink voice commands to retrieve the information from your phone. Sync Destinations makes it easy to manage the carpool or survive running a long day of errands because it will show you when you’ll arrive at each saved destination if you leave immediately. It can also tell if the commute will get better or worse if you adjust your departure time. But it would be nice if it went one step further and told you the optimal order in which to make each stop.
$295. Sync services is free for three years, $60 per year thereafter.

title: 2013 Toyota Avalon
subTitle: Still Toyota’s boulevard barge, now with a bodacious bod.
promoTeaserSmall: Still Toyota’s boulevard barge, now with a bodacious bod.
promoTeaser: Still Toyota’s boulevard barge, now with a bodacious bod.
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Avalon - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Avalon here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Since Toyota first launched the Avalon in the 1990s, the full-size four-door has been Toyota’s version of the Buick: comfy, quiet, and easy to digest. As the Toyota brand’s flagship, the Avalon has enjoyed popularity among the retiree set as well as among satisfied Camry customers who simply want a little bit more, in the form of an extra-wide cabin, a Costco-grade trunk, a high level of creature comforts, and a schmaltzy ride. But the all-new 2013 Avalon has evolved into something more than a Camry. It has become lighter in weight and shorter in both height and length, making it one of the more garage-friendly full-size sedans around. Just as significant, the Avalon has upgraded almost everything under the skin, and now it shares pretty much all of its innards with none other than the slick new 2013 Lexus ES. Like the Lexus, the Avalon is powered by a silken, powerful 3.5-liter V-6 with 268 horsepower in standard form, or a four-cylinder/electric powertrain combo in the new-for-2013 Avalon hybrid that scores an EPA rating of 40 mpg. The 2013 Avalon was designed in California and brandishes a glitzy new grille, LED running lamps, sweeping body sides, and an elegantly arching roof. But the Avalon’s new interior may be its best attribute, offering not just tons of space but far more luxury experience than ever, thanks to additional sound-deadening materials, hand-stitched dash covers, capacitive touch controls, and lots of fancy options including heated front and rear seats and soft ambient lighting.

title: 2013 Toyota Camry
subTitle: In the face of strong competition, the Camry remains competitive. For now.
promoTeaserSmall: In the face of strong competition, the Camry remains competitive. For now.
promoTeaser: In the face of strong competition, the Camry remains competitive. For now.
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Camry
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Camry here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: From the Don’t Mess with a Good Thing department comes the 2013 Toyota Camry. Still looking fresh after its complete redesign for the 2012 model year, Toyota’s perennial bestseller is unchanged for 2013, and that’s generally fine by us, as Toyota did a remarkable job adding emotion to the Camry this time around (not too much, of course…2012 is an election year, after all). Not only does its styling actually convey, well, actual style from its broad, beveled mug to its chunky, L-shaped taillamps, but it drives pretty well, too, with taut suspensions and communicative steering. Three engine choices await customers, including a frugal 178-horsepower four-cylinder, a velvety 268-horsepower V-6, and a four-cylinder/electric hybrid, the latter helping the Camry hybrid achieve an impressive 41-mpg rating from the EPA. The interior still suffers from some corporate boardroom austerity, but it is comfortably equipped even in base form and feels Lexus-like in uplevel XLE form. And of course, since it’s a Toyota, assembly quality is pretty spectacular. As good as it is, however, the Camry will have a tougher time than ever keeping its sales crown this year, with stiff new competition coming from the Ford Fusion, the Chevrolet Malibu, the Nissan Altima, and the Camry’s arch-nemesis, the Honda Accord, each of which should also be checked out by mid-size sedan shoppers before plunking down their money for a Camry.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Nissan Altima
2. Chevrolet Malibu
3. Honda Accord

Cool Tech Items:
1. HD radio with iTunes song tagging.
2. Smart Stop Technology brake override system.
3. EnTune mutlimedia system with Bing, OpenTable, and Pandora apps, among others.

Looks:
1. SE model with unique front end and lower body styling.
2. Stitching and chrome and aluminum trim throughout interior.
3. Available navigation system with split-screen display to show audio and map simultaneously.

title: 2013 Toyota Sienna
subTitle: The corporate boardroom of minivans.
promoTeaserSmall: The corporate boardroom of minivans.
promoTeaser: The corporate boardroom of minivans.
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Sienna - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Sienna here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Of the five major minivans on the market today, Toyota’s Sienna is arguably the most sterile. Huge, clean, and full of storage cubbies and sliding things, the Sienna could double as a hospital if it only came with a gurney. But there’s more to the Sienna than just seats and space. Five trim levels are available, ranging from basic to truly luxurious, with a surprisingly decent-looking SE model adding a touch of sportiness to the lineup. As with most of its competitors, the Sienna can host up to eight at a time, with seats that can be inclined, reclined, slid, stowed, and flattened in countless combinations. One particularly cool feature is the 16.4-inch-wide, remote-controlled rear entertainment screen that can play two different videos side by side. Another is the nifty front center console that can be slid rearward so second-row occupants can reach it. The sole powerplant is Toyota’s smooth and quiet 266-horsepower V-6, mated to a six-speed automatic transmission, which helps it achieve a respectable 18/25 mpg city/highway fuel economy rating from the EPA. The Honda Odyssey may be better-looking and the Chrysler Town & Country more fun to drive, but neither will have an easy time keeping up with the Sienna on a snowy road, as the Sienna is the industry’s first minivan to offer all-wheel drive (although choosing one so equipped drops fuel economy by two miles per gallon). If there’s a bone to pick with the Sienna, it’s that it is simply not very emotional. But then again, what hospital is?
Fun-O-Meter: 3

Competitors:
1. Nissan Quest
2. Honda Odyssey
3. Chrysler Town and Country

Cool Tech Items:
1. Dual-display 16.4-inch rear entertainment screen.
2. Rear sonar, pre-collision system, and radar-based cruise control available on Limited.
3. Independently sliding dual moonroofs on Limited.

Looks:
1. Nineteen-inch wheels, sportier front and rear styling on SE.
2. Lounge-style second-row seating on Limited.
3. Clever sliding center console for use by front or second-row seats.

New for 2013:
1. Standard blind spot monitor on XLE and Limited (optional on SE).
2. Four-cylinder discontinued; V-6 standard.
3. Available all-wheel drive.

title: 2013 Toyota Tacoma
subTitle: Toyota still makes the best not-so-compact compact truck around.
promoTeaserSmall: Toyota still makes the best not-so-compact compact truck around.
promoTeaser: Toyota still makes the best not-so-compact compact truck around.
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Tacoma - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Tacoma here at JeanKnowCars.com

pageElements.text: Toyota has been selling compact trucks here for more than forty years and, well, all we can say is, “My, how you’ve grown!” What started as a Lilliputian trucklet in the late 1960s that put the “toy” in Toyota has developed into a rugged, imposing, nearly full-size workhorse, adopting the name Tacoma somewhere along the way. Thank Toyota’s steady-handed stewardship of its signature truck for its intensely loyal following that has kept the model selling in droves even as competitors have come and gone. In 2013, the Tacoma’s sole direct competitor is the comparatively gruff Nissan Frontier, and with its winning combination of slick looks, sterling build quality, bountiful comfort levels, and cab styles (including a simple standard cab model), the Tacoma is arguably the superior of the two. The Tacoma looks particularly good as the low-riding XRunner and the high-riding PreRunner, the latter even more so when you splurge on the T|X and T|X Pro packages. Anyone fancying a bit more cush should like the new Limited grade, with its chrome exterior trim, metallic dash surfaces, heated front seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, and more. As before, a 159-horsepower four-cylinder is the base engine, while the bulk of models and all 4x4s come standard with a 236-horsepower V-6. We recommend the V-6 if you ever plan to get out of your own way, let alone carry a load in the bed. After all, isn’t that what trucks are for?
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Nissan Frontier
2. Honda Ridgeline

Cool Tech Items:
1. Power boost to 304 horsepower with TRD V-6 supercharger kit.
2. Available locking rear differential with PreRunner 4X4 and TRD packages.

Looks:
1. Menacing appearance with T|X and T|X Pro packages.
2. Water-resistant seats on TRD Sport and Off-Road packages.
3. Chrome trim, upgraded interior on Limited package.

New for 2013:
1. Limited Package.

title: 2013 Volvo C30
subTitle: What to do with an unexpectedly popular model? Turn up the sport
promoTeaserSmall: What to do with an unexpectedly popular model? Turn up the sport
promoTeaser: What to do with an unexpectedly popular model? Turn up the sport
metaTitle: 2013 Volvo C30 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Volvo C30 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Since its American debut in 2008, buyers have embraced the Volvo C30 as a bellwether of Scandinavian design. External proportions and details are just right, and the interior is impeccable. With a lusty, turbocharged five-cylinder engine producing 227 horsepower, your choice of a six-speed manual or five-speed automatic transmission, and the sophisticated suspension, the C30 is a delight to drive. It seats four, just like a Porsche Panamera, but you won’t feel anything is wasted. The C30 is available in T5 and T5 R-Design versions, each with Premier, Premier Plus, and Platinum trim levels. The Platinum includes power-operated front seats and sunroof, keyless start, active Xenon headlamps, navigation, and a killer sound system. The C30 Polestar Limited Edition makes its debut in October, but only 250 examples--all in the same hue of Rebel Blue--will reach American showrooms. Polestar is Volvo’s performance subbrand, similar to M at BMW and AMG at Mercedes-Benz; revisions to the engine result in 250 horsepower, and the car rides on unique matte black seventeen-inch wheels. Premier Plus trim is standard for the Polestar, with Platinum optional. The C30 is expensive to build in Belgium for U.S. sale, but Volvo’s loss is our gain.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi A3
2. Mini Cooper
3. Volkswagen GTI

Cool Tech Items:
1. The C30’s mobile phone app, an extension of Volvo On Call, allows the owner to stay in touch with the parked car for a range of connectivity possibilities.
2. As one might expect of a Swedish car made in Europe, a cold weather package that includes heated front seats and electronic climate control is available.
3. The available blind spot information system alerts the driver to nearby objects.

Looks:
1.Titanium Gray and Electric Silver metallic paint colors are available.
2. A wood-rimmed sport steering wheel is available.
3. Blond leather upholstery is available.

New for 2013:
1. Rain-sensing windshield wipers and headlight washers are now standard.
2. Seventeen-inch “Spider” alloy wheels are offered.
3. The sportier Polestar Limited Edition is available in a run of just 250 units for the United States.

title: 2013 Volvo S80
subTitle: Smart and well equipped, the S80 also has a stealth factor. Not because Volvo wants it that way.
promoTeaserSmall: Smart and well equipped, the S80 also has a stealth factor. Not because Volvo wants it that way.
promoTeaser: Smart and well equipped, the S80 also has a stealth factor. Not because Volvo wants it that way.
metaTitle: 2013 Volvo S80 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Volvo S80 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The S80 represented Volvo’s first foray away from boxy sedans. The company now applies the word “exclusive” to the car, although this is because it doesn’t sell very well. The only good explanation for the slow sales, though, is that snob appeal is lacking. This handsome, if understated, sedan is smooth on the road and well equipped. It offers a good value equation. You’ll find such unexpected standard features as Volvo’s City Safety system for avoiding low-speed collisions and the available blind spot monitoring and pedestrian detection. The cabin, richly appointed with leather and walnut, can be overpopulated with twelve speakers for a wonderful music environment. Americans choose from two models. The 3.2 is powered by a 240-horsepower 3.2-liter six-cylinder engine. A smaller, turbocharged 3.0-liter six makes 300 horsepower to move the T6 AWD smartly down the road. The two models share the same six-speed automatic. The S80 is Volvo’s technology leader: it introduced keyless start and Personal Car Communicator, a key fob that foretells unlocked doors and vehicle intrusion, and this is now standard. A smartphone app is also available for staying connected with the S80. Anyone seeking value and high-level content wouldn’t be called a rotten herring for picking the S80.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Audi A6
2. Lincoln MKS
3. Acura RL

Cool Tech Items:
1. Headlights gain “tunnel detection” for automatic brightening inside tunnels.
2. Road sign information feature displays road signs in the instrument cluster.
3. Keyless start with the super-smart Personal Car Communicator key fob is now standard.

Looks:
1. By our count, no fewer than twenty-one different wheels, ranging from sixteen to eighteen inches, are offered.
2. Illuminated sill moldings welcome every occupant who enters the car.
3. Magic Blue Metallic and Twilight Bronze Metallic join the color chart.

New for 2013:
1. The six-speed automatic in the T6 AWD now has a sport mode and an illuminated shift knob for the different modes.
2. Rain-sensing windshield wipers are standard.
3. Headlight washers are standard.

title: 2013 Volvo XC70
subTitle: In the winter of her career, an old dame reminds us of her previous breakthrough performances.
promoTeaserSmall: In the winter of her career, an old dame reminds us of her previous breakthrough performances.
promoTeaser: In the winter of her career, an old dame reminds us of her previous breakthrough performances.
metaTitle: 2013 Volvo XC70 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Volvo XC70 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The XC70 was Volvo’s answer to the Subaru Outback and the precursor of the Swedish brand’s crossover SUVs. It was a regular Volvo station wagon lifted up for more ground clearance and girded for battle with climatological and geological residuum. Sturdy and swift, the V70 enjoyed strong sales until the company’s SUVs, particularly the XC60, made it appear somewhat redundant in Volvo’s lineup. Nevertheless, a market niche remains, and the XC70 continues to occupy it. Two versions are available: the 3.2 and the T6 AWD. The former’s 3.2-liter six-cylinder makes 240 horsepower, while the latter’s turbocharged 3.0-liter six makes 300 horsepower. A six-speed automatic is included with either model. Beyond the base 3.2 are Premier, Premier Plus, and Platinum trim levels, while the T6 AWD also comes in Premier Plus and Platinum trim. The T6 AWD comes with a remote garage door opener, keyless start with a key fob that plays detective before you open the door, active Xenon headlamps that look around the corners for you, a power moonroof and tailgate, and other amenities. Heated front and rear seats available with climate package and heated washer fluid nozzles help make the XC70 one of the most serious winter cars in the marketplace.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Audi Allroad
2. Subaru Outback
3. Ford Edge

Cool Tech Items:
1. Navigation-based road sign information, along with active high-beam headlamps, is available with the technology package.
2. Headlights gain “tunnel detection” for automatic brightening inside tunnels.
3. Keyless start with the super-smart Personal Car Communicator key fob is now standard with the T6 AWD.

Looks:
1. Accessory mud flaps are somehow perfect on the XC70, but the rear spoiler, while functional, just looks wrong.
2. There’s a bevy of alloy wheels in unique designs, from sixteen to eighteen inches in diameter.
3. The XC70 is probably available with as wide a selection of cargo-area accessories, roof racks, and roof storage boxes as any other car, at least from Sweden.

New for 2013:
1. Standard rain-sensing windshield wipers and headlamp washers.
2. The six-speed automatic in the T6 AWD now has a sport mode and an illuminated shift knob for the different modes.
3. Increased functionality for steering wheel scroll control.

title: 2013 Dodge Charger
subTitle: A whole lot of car, with a whole lot of attitude.
promoTeaserSmall: A whole lot of car, with a whole lot of attitude.
promoTeaser: A whole lot of car, with a whole lot of attitude.
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Charger - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Charger here at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: With the Dukes of Hazzard’s General Lee in its bloodline, the 2013 Dodge Charger certainly has attitude. What other car, besides its corporate cousin the Chrysler 300, can be the perfect family car by day and star in rap videos by night? With rear-wheel drive or on-demand all-wheel drive, the Charger has also become the darling of law enforcement, if that means anything to you (just don’t expect it to get you out of any speeding tickets, trust us). Still, there are many reasons it can wear so many hats. First, it looks great, with a menacing stare and many Mopar accessories available to help you customize it to your liking (the Blacktop package is particularly hot, we think). It also has some chops, with a base V-6 making 292 horsepower, mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission that helps the big girl achieve 31 mpg on the highway. Spring for the 370-horsepower V-8 and it becomes downright fast, and for speed demons, a scary-looking 470-horsepower SRT-8 model is pure hooligan heaven. Finally, the Charger has a value story to tell, with base models starting under $26,000 (less than a V-6-equipped Toyota Camry), and dashboard trim rendered in real aluminum. Optional are sport seats, a simple Garmin-based navigation/infotainment system using a huge 8.4-inch screen, and even a Beats by Dr. Dre sound system. A full-size sedan with full-size character, the Dodge Charger is as American as a car gets.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Ford Taurus
2. VW Passat
3. Chrysler 300

Cool Tech items
1. Available Beats by Dr. Dre sound system.
2. Brakes with rain-brake support.
3. Fuel-saving cylinder de-activation.

Looks
1. V-6 Rallye appearance and Blacktop packages with twenty-inch wheels, sport seats, spoiler.
2. Steering wheel paddle-shifters for R/T Road & Track package.
3. Get-outa-my-way styling on SRT8 model.

New for 2013
1. Available on-demand all-wheel drive.
2. New colors: TorRed (SRT8 only), Billet Silver, Copperhead Pearl, Granite Crystal Pearl, Jazz Blue Pearl, Phantom Black.
3. Available black-painted roof.

title: 2013 Acura ZDX
subTitle: The ZDX resists categorization, but that’s not always a bad thing.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Acura ZDX
promoTeaser: 2013 Acura ZDX
metaTitle: 2013 Acura ZDX Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura ZDX Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 ZDX continues that model’s tradition as the odd cousin of the Acura brand. It looks like a coupe, but it has the Acura MDX’s much larger platform and 300-horsepower V-6 engine. It has more cargo space than a sedan, but less than most crossovers. And if you’re tall, you may find the high floor and low ceiling confining. That said, the ZDX doesn’t disappoint on power or handling. It comes with Acura’s supremely effective all-wheel-drive system and can keep the car under control even with a sprightly driver behind the wheel. The ZDX has distinctive exterior styling that makes it a controversial entry into Acura’s brand, but it is certainly more interesting and sporty than some other crossovers. New for 2013 are an optional technology package with leather seats, keyless entry and push-button start, and a fancy new navigation system with real-time traffic rerouting that could shave seconds off your commute. Even if you don’t feel like shelling out for the extras, a base model includes a leather dash and a convenient USB jack and auxiliary audio input for direct connectivity to an iPod or other device.

Fun-O-Meter:
7

Competitors:
1. BMW X6
2. Infiniti FX
3. Volvo XC60

Cool Tech:
1. New navigation system with traffic re-routing.
2. USB and auxiliary input jacks.

Looks:
1. Leather dash and steering wheel, available leather seats.
2. LED backlighting throughout.

New for 2013:
1. Available technology package.
2. Exterior redesign.

title: 2013 Nissan Armada
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Armada is an old-school SUV designed to appeal to shoppers who need brawny performance and good towing capabilities – and never look twice at prices at the gas pump.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Armada
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Armada
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Armada Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Armada here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan Armada takes it moniker from a famous fleet of Spanish warships and the giant SUV certainly lives up to its name. It offers beefy, all-weather performance, good towing capabilities and a rugged, utilitarian interior. The muscular Armada can tow up to 9,000 pounds and tackle the outdoors, thanks to its truck chassis and low-range four-wheel drive that can handle extreme towing or off-roading needs. A third-row seat is standard and eight passengers can ride comfortably in the spacious Armada. Its standard engine, a 5.6-liter V-8, is rated at 317 horsepower. The engine is linked to a five-speed automatic transmission. But the Armada is thirsty, delivering 12 mpg in city driving and 19 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The Armada, which has a heavy-duty, fully boxed ladder frame, drives like a truck and can be a beast to maneuver into tight parking spaces. Although the interior on the base model feels somewhat cheap, Nissan continues to offer packages that dress up the cabin. For 2013, a new Platinum Reserve package debuts, adding twenty-inch dark chrome wheels, dark chrome grille, and outside mirrors, along with a two-tone Chocolate/Almond leather-trimmed seating with dark satin chrome interior accents. If $4-a-gallon gas prices don’t bother you, the Armada may be a logical choice.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1.Toyota Sequoia
2. Ford Expedition
3. Chevrolet Tahoe
4. GMC Yukon

New for 2013:
1. New Platinum Reserve package adds twenty-inch dark chrome wheels, dark chrome grille and outside mirrors, Chocolate/Almond leather-trimmed seating, and dark satin chrome interior accents.
2. Dual seven-inch headrest system added to Platinum models, available on SV and SL models.
3. Slide-on-rod sunvisors with mirror and illumination now standard on all models.
4. Bluetooth added as standard on SV models.
5. Five new exterior colors include Midnight Garnet, Graphite Blue, Gun Metallic, Pearl White, and Java Metallic.

title: 2013 Audi Allroad
subTitle: The Allroad is back from retirement
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Audi Allroad
promoTeaser: 2013 Audi Allroad
metaTitle: 2013 Audi Allroad Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi Allroad Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Audi will reintroduce the Allroad for 2013, after excluding it from the lineup for seven years. The Allroad is longer and a little higher off the ground than previous models, which gives it more clearance to better handle varying terrain. Audi does not sacrifice style for performance, and the Allroad is attractive, despite having a very wagon-ish feel. Audi’s trademark grille and headlight styling are prominent in the Allroad, and the interior is much more spacious than Audi’s sedans. New seating allows more headroom for passengers, and there is plenty of storage space for bags or gear.  Audi’s new Connect technology can make use of Google Earth connectivity and turn the car into a roving hotspot. There is an available Bang & Olufsen sound system, though it is almost prohibitively expensive and requires an upgrade to the Prestige trim level. Features that come standard in other Audis need to be purchased for the Allroad, but with its $39,000 base price (one of the lowest in Audi’s fleet) and all the benefit of Audi’s fine engineering the Allroad is still a good car for the money.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Volvo XC70
2. BMW X3
3. Cadillac SRX

Cool Tech:
1. Adaptive cruise control automatically reacts to other cars and road conditions.
2. Audi MMI technology and Bang & Olufsen sound system available.
3. Available Audi side assist for safety.

Looks:
1. Distinctive Audi headlights and grille.
2. Panoramic sunroof.
3. Attractive interior with available wood grain trim.

New for 2013:
1. An all-new reboot.

title: 2013 Audi Q7
subTitle: A little bulky, but still an Audi
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Audi Q7
promoTeaser: 2013 Audi Q7
metaTitle: 2013 Audi Q7 - Buyer's Guide
metaDescription: 2013 Audi Q7 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Audi’s biggest car has some minor changes for the 2013 model year, but the basic package remains the same. The Q7 fits Audi’s model of good engineering, speed, and luscious interiors. Where it breaks the mold, of course, is in sheer size. With three spacious rows of seats, it can fit up to seven people; with all the seats down, it can fit pretty much anything you can think of. Audi axed a V-8 engine in 2012, and this year they have gone even further toward improving fuel efficiency by offering a new, lighter V-6 diesel engine that is twelve percent more fuel-efficient than previous diesel models, earning an impressive 28 mpg on the highway. The Q7 hasn’t received a major redesign in some years, and its age is showing, but with an updated grille and headlights on the 2013 model, some of that will be mitigated. The design of the interior will remain much the same, but available technology packages could turn the Q7 into your home away from home. The premium packages are rather expensive, but if you’ve got the money, you’re not likely to regret it. Options include a Bang & Olufsen sound system, a new split-screen rear video monitor, and Audi MMI technology.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. BMW X5
2. Infiniti QX
3. Lexus LX

Cool Tech:
1. Available Bang & Olufsen sound system.
2. Available safety technology like lane assist and Pre-Sense to help during collisions.
3. New engine for diesel model, sedan-like fuel economy.

Looks:
1. Audi’s most spacious vehicle.
2. Available panoramic roof.
3. Available rear entertainment system.

New for 2013:
1. More efficient V-6 engine.
2. Available Audi MMI.

title: 2013 Nissan Leaf
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Leaf, an electric car, lets you drive past gas stations – but you will pay a price.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Leaf
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Leaf
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Leaf ATS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Cadillac ATS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Leaf is in the vanguard of electric cars coming on the market in the U.S. It’s kind to the environment and it has become increasingly attractive, especially in an era of $4-a-gallon gasoline. But the EPA rates the Leaf’s driving range at 73 miles per charge – which makes the little EV impractical for anyone with a long commute. The federal government says there are only 4,466 public charging stations in the U.S., a statistic that may increase “range anxiety” for anyone who owns or is thinking about buying an electric car. Still, the Leaf has a lot going for it. The price is good for an electric car and the Leaf is eligible for federal and state incentives that can help to defray the cost. It drives like a “real” car with sprightly acceleration, zero tailpipe emissions, and a 90-mph top speed. The EPA rates the Leaf at the miles-per-gallon equivalent of 106 in the city and 92 on the highway – the second most fuel-efficient car in America after the Mitsubishi i. The downside is that Leaf home charging can take up to twenty hours without an optional quick charging station. The range can also vary depending on the weather and how much cargo you are carrying. The Leaf suffers from tight rear seats, small cargo space for a hatchback, and confusing cabin technology. But if you have short commutes, have no fear of running out of juice, and want to boost your green credentials, the Leaf may be the way to go.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Focus Electric
2. Chevrolet Volt
3. Mitsubishi i
4. Toyota Prius

Cool Tech:
1. Owners can communicate with the Nissan Leaf remotely through their smartphones and computer through the Carwings system. The system lets them track the battery’s charge, save on energy costs by scheduling off-peak charging and pre-set the heat or A/C functions.

New for 2013:
1. Nissan says details on the 2013 Leaf will be available at a later date.

title: 2013 Nissan Murano
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Murano provides fun and good fuel economy from a crossover champ.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Murano
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Murano
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Murano Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Murano here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan Murano used to stand alone in the crossover market as one of the few truly stylish offerings. That’s no longer the case, but the five-passenger Murano still is a solid competitor, especially for those looking for fun and good fuel economy. The one downside is that the Murano tends to be a bit expensive. What you get for the money is a pleasing exterior design that remains unchanged for the new model year. A wide chrome-and-mesh grille and triangular headlights prove to be a dramatic combination in the front, while a roof spoiler adds interest in the rear. Nissan beefed up the Murano for 2013 with advanced safety technologies added to the uplevel LE Platinum Edition and SL Navigation Package. The Murano again offers a standard 260-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 linked to an Xtronic CVT. The combination offers smooth, powerful acceleration and returns 18 mpg in city driving and 24 mpg on the highway on the Murano front-wheel-drive model and 18 mpg in city driving and 23 mpg on the highway on the four-wheel-drive model. The ride is comfortable and relatively soft. A long list of options includes a dual panel power moonroof, eight-way power driver’s seat with power lumbar support, and SiriusXM satellite radio. The Murano is an excellent choice for small families who don’t want to sacrifice sensibility for style. You get both with this Japanese crossover.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Edge
2. Honda CR-V
3. Mazda CX-5
4. Toyota Venza

Cool Tech:
1. Moving object detection helps the driver keep track of what’s going on outside the vehicle.

New for 2013:
1. Advanced safety shield technologies, including moving object detection, blind-sport warning and lane-departure warning systems added to LE platinum edition and SL navigation package.
2. A new SV value package with power liftgate, Bose Audio system with nine speakers and Nissan navigation system for SV models.
3. A new Titanium finish added to the eighteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels on SV value package and SL models.
4. SV models get an auto-dimming rearview mirror and HomeLink.
5. Midnight Garnet and Gun Metallic are two new exterior colors.

title: 2013 Bentley Continental GT
subTitle: The world is yours when you’re driving the dashing Bentley GT coupe.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Bentley Continental GT
promoTeaser: 2013 Bentley Continental GT
metaTitle: 2013 Bentley Continental GT Buyer's Guide - Jean Know Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Bentley Continental GT Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: You know you’re in the money when you’re driving the new Continental GTC, which is the convertible version of the two-door Bentley. In literal terms, the car is priced well over $200,000. Shopping for a Bentley is a not an off-the-rack experience. Here there are plenty of options in a neat laundry list including possible fabric and color combinations.  The Bentley GT is big and powerful, but surprisingly easy to drive, which sets it apart from other fussy, super-luxury cars with extra-sensitive gas pedals. The two-door Bentley was refreshed in 2011 followed by the 2012 convertible GTC. Bentley has broadened its engine portfolio, starting with its badass W-12 and now introducing the less thirsty and much thriftier V-8, which manages to pack a wallop of power. Next comes the GT Speed coming in September 2012 that, rumor has it, will be the fastest Bentley ever. Choose your poison, either way the GT is made for maxing and relaxing.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. BMW M6 Coupe
2. Aston Martin DBS
3. Mercedes-Benz CL63 AMG

Cool Tech:
1. You’ll find star-bright LED lamps.
2. At last Bentley has incorporation a much-improved touch screen navigation system.

Looks
1. Unlike past Bentley designs, the cabin is more futuristic than old library with "blood orange" illumination.
2. The natural leathers and hand-polished woods give the Bentley interiors a feeling of authenticity.

New for 2013
1. The V-8 gets a new grille and Bentley "B" set in a red background.
2. Bentley adds the more fuel-efficient V-8 engine to its lineup of super cars.
3. The Bentley is more "B" for boss with standard twenty-inch wheels.

title: 2013 BMW 5-Series
subTitle: The familiar executive sedan also bridges the gap to realm of utility.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 BMW 5-Series
promoTeaser: 2013 BMW 5-Series
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 5-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 5-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Whether you need cargo-carrying capacity or an executive express, the 5-series has you covered. The lineup’s oddity is the Gran Turismo. Its curved back bridges the gap between station wagon (one isn’t offered) and SUV. No holding it down, though, because it employs the same 400-horsepower twin-turbo V-8 and eight-speed automatic transmission from the 550i sedan. Or, you can settle for the 300-horsepower version of the turbo six-cylinder from the 535i sedan--not brutally fast but still pretty quick. Among the sedan entries, there’s also the 528i. Remarkably for this class and price range, the 528i goes about its business with a turbo four-cylinder. Then there’s the ActiveHybrid 5, in which the turbo six is assisted by an electric motor, their output going through an eight-speed transmission. As quick as it can be, the ActiveHybrid 5 can also creep along solely on battery power for 2.5 miles. Ask your neighbor if his Blutomobile can do that! Efficiency is spreading across the 5-series range, too, thanks to the automatic stop/start, which completely shuts off the engine while you sit at intersections, then restarts it when you release the brake. So every member of the 5-series is handsome, or at least interesting, luxurious, and full of advanced technology.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Mercedes-Benz E-Class
2. Cadillac CTS
3. Infiniti M-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Optional, dazzling 10.25-in display is shared with 7-series.
2. ActiveHybrid 5 can reach 37 mph inch all-electric mode.
3. ActiveHybrid 5 has electronics that work with navigation to “read” the route, storing electrical power for uphill stretches.

Looks
1. ActiveHybrid 5 also has galvanized grille slats and matte chrome exhaust tips.
2. You know the battery pack in the luggage area by its "ActiveHybrid Power Unit" inscription.
3. A black-panel display presents instruments and driver information.

title: 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan
subTitle: The Grand Caravan may be more fun to drive than it is to look at, but America’s original minivan remains very easy to live with.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan
promoTeaser: 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: You may not know it by looking at it, but the Dodge Grand Caravan may be the most enjoyable-to-drive minivan you can buy. Yeah, it’s not often that the words “minivan” and “fun to drive” are used in the same sentence, but in this case—and that of the GC’s Chrysler-branded twin, the Town & Country—it’s the surprising reality. Credit thorough re-engineering for 2011 that banished the sloppy handling and gooey steering usually associated with such domesticated vehicles. Less surprising is the way it accommodates families with up to seven members and all of their attendant accoutrements. In addition to the abundant space, kid stuff—and the second- or third-row seats themselves—may be stowed (with one-handed operation) in deep reservoirs in the floor of most models. The GC comes in five flavors: AVP, SE, SXT, Crew, and R/T, the first two priced very aggressively (the AVP starts under $21,000), and the latter three featuring the highest amount of popular equipment. Our favorite is the R/T model (which Dodge has lightheartedly referred to as the “man van,” with its monochromatic paint, a tighter suspension, seventeen-inch satin carbon wheels, black leather upholstery, red stitching, and a whomping sound system. All Grand Caravans are powered by the same meaty 283-horsepower V-6 mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. Compared with the Honda Odyssey and Toyota Sienna, the Grand Caravan may be a tad smaller, but it is tons more fun.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Nissan Quest
2. Honda Odyssey
3. Toyota Sienna

Cool Tech Items:
1. Safety Sphere package with park assist, backup camera, blind spot assist, rear cross path detection.
2. Stow-in-place roof rails with scissor-style roof bows.
3. Third-row powered rear vent windows.

Looks:
1. R/T model with sport-themed interior, exterior treatment, subwoofer.
2. Black/sandstorm interior color combo available for non-R/T models.

New for 2013:
1. Prices lowered on some models.
2. Rear-seat entertainment with Blu-ray player, dual nine-inch screens.
3. Billet Silver, Maximum Steel and Blue Streak exterior colors added.

title: 2013 Cadillac CTS
subTitle: Cadillac CTS and CTS-V run the gamut from reasonably sporting to outrageously sporting
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Cadillac CTS/CTS-V
promoTeaser: 2013 Cadillac CTS/CTS-V
metaTitle: 2013 Cadillac CTS/CTS-V Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Cadillac CTS/CTS-V Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Cadillac CTS family of cars includes sedan, coupe, and wagon body styles and CTS and CTS-V versions. All this choice lets you decide where you fall on the spectrum of desire: are you shopping Cadillac because you’re looking for a traditional plush sedan, a testosterone-spouting luxury sports car, or a little of each? For starters, there’s the very competent “regular” CTS, powered by a pair of V-6 engine choices. The rear-wheel-drive CTS sedan and coupe ride on the same wheelbase, but the coupe is about two inches lower and two inches shorter, with a more steeply angled windshield. All three CTS body styles get the same 27 mpg on the highway. Get the Touring or Performance versions for more of a kick, or the Sport Wagon for more versatility. Then there’s the CTS-V, which famously set a speed record at the Nürburgring race circuit in Germany a few years back. It’s set up for performance with Brembo brakes, an airflow-improving grille, performance tires, a set of center-mounted, mouthy tailpipes, and, last but not least, a supercharged V-8 engine that puts out 556 horsepower—and helps limit fuel economy to a maximum of 19 mpg on the highway.
Fun-O-Meter: 7 to 9

Competitors:
1. Audi A4/S4/S5
2. BMW 3 Series and M3
3. Infiniti G37
4. Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Two-piece front brake rotors (cut down on warping, reduce weight, longer lived) new for 2013.

Looks:
1. Optional Brembo red brake calipers on CTS-V.

New for 2013:
1. All now standard: heated leather seating with ten-way power-adjustable driver and front passenger seats with driver’s memory feature, adaptive remote starting, rearview camera system, Rainsense wipers, interior ambient lighting, Universal Home Remote and an underhood appearance package.

title: 2013 Cadillac SRX
subTitle: Cadillac adds more electronics and technology, plus some cosmetic upgrades, to burnish the luster of this luxury crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Cadillac SRX
promoTeaser: 2013 Cadillac SRX
metaTitle: 2013 Cadillac SRX Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Cadillac SRX Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: As it made its place in the competitive world of crossover vehicles, Cadillac’s mid-size SRX has gone through several changes: from its origins as a rear-wheel-drive vehicle to its current front-/all-wheel-drive setup, from a seven-seat to a five-seat vehicle, and from a pair of V-6s, one of which was a turbo, to a single, higher-horsepower V-6 engine. For 2013, changes to the SRX are evolutionary. The front upper and lower grilles have been updated, and the interior gets upgraded technology. Among the safety improvements is the interesting Safety Alert Seat, which vibrates one of the driver’s seat bolsters when there’s a perceived danger such as too close proximity to an object such as a tree or another vehicle.  There’s also adaptive cruise control and automatic braking, both of which rely on radar and sensors to the extent of actually putting on the brake for you if danger is imminent. The SRX also has Cadillac’s new Cue information and entertainment system, which triggered a redesign of the intstrument cluster and center stack, plus such luxury amenities as a rearview camera, heated front seats, a leather-trimmed steering wheel—you can get it heated as well—and a power sunroof. Performance and Premium versions get some new twenty-inch wheel designs. You can dress up the SRX’s interior with an all-black look to go with the French stitching and polished chrome, and there’s even sapele wood trim as an option.
Fun-O-Meter: 7.5

Competitors:
1. BMW X3
2. Lexus RX350
3. Lincoln MKX
4. Volvo XC60

Cool Tech:
1. Cue information and entertainment system new this year.
2. Active noise cancellation.
3. Safety Alert Seat.

Looks
1. Twenty-inch wheel designs added for top two trim levels.
2. Three new metallic exterior colors (Evolution Green, Glacier Blue, and Silver Coast), wood accent color (Raven Sapele), and interior color combination (Light Titanium).

New for 2013
1. Active noise cancellation.
2. Cadillac Cue part of a revised interior design.
3. Upper and lower grille design tweaks.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Avalanche
subTitle: 2013 is the end of the road for the SUV that can turn into a truck
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Chevrolet Avalanche
promoTeaser: 2013 Chevrolet Avalanche
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Avalanche Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Chevrolet Avalanche Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Avalanche, which transforms from a five- or six-passenger SUV to a pickup and back again, has entered its final model year after a run that has lasted since the 2002 model year. GM is marking all 2013 models with special Black Diamond badging as a tribute. Every 2013 Avalanche also has a standard rear-view camera, ultrasonic parking assist, a remote starter, power-adjustable pedals, and body-color bed surrounds. The most distinctive feature of the Avalanche is the transformation wrought with the Midgate. Once you fold the rear seats down, you can tip the rear cabin wall into the cab, giving you a three-foot gain in bed length, to eight feet, two inches, for cargo. With the tailgate shut, you can fit a four-by-eight foot sheet of plywood or 45.5 cubic feet of whatever else you’ve got. The top-level LTZ has a heated steering wheel and heated and cooled front leather-appointed seats. The Avalanche’s swan song is topped off with a $2,500 cut to base pricing, down to $35,980 plus $995 destination for the base rear-wheel-drive LS model.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford F-150 SuperCrew
2. Honda Ridgeline
3. Ram 1500 Quad Cab

Cool Tech:
1. Moveable midgate offers increased space in bed.
2. Rearview camera and parking assist.

Looks
1. Black Diamond badge on all 2013 models.
2. Can seat up to six.

title: 2013 Fisker Karma
subTitle: An electric hybrid that isn’t an eyesore
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Fisker Karma
promoTeaser: 2013 Fisker Karma
metaTitle: 2013 Fisker Karma Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Fisker Karma Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If the Fisker name doesn’t sound familiar, that’s because this American carmaker is only five years old. The plug-in hybrid Karma is the only Fisker model currently on sale, and with a price hovering around $100,000 it is no impulse buy. The Karma aims to illustrate that environmentally friendly doesn’t mean boring, and in that right they have certainly succeeded. The Karma’s batteries have a range of about fifty miles, after which a gas engine takes over until batteries are recharged. At times, for instance during fast acceleration, the Karma operates using both battery and gas engine power.  For even more eco-friendliness, the Karma has a solar panel roof that increases the electric range by about four to five miles per week. Those extra miles won’t get you far, but it still adds a certain car-of-the-future feel to Fisker’s first offering. When it’s running on electric, the Karma gets an impressive 54 miles to the gallon equivalent. On the gas motor, however, it earns an entirely unimpressive 20-mpg combined. This relatively low number belies the Karma’s true spirit – that of a luxury sports car. With an attractive interior, unforgettable design, and innovative technology, the Karma can’t fail to make a statement.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Aston Martin Rapide
2. Maserati Quattroporte
3. Jaguar XJ

Cool Tech:
1. Solar panel roof.
2. Fifty mile electric fuel range.
3. Ten-inch touch screen infotainment system.

Looks:
1. Animal-free interior.
2. Attractive, distinctive exterior styling.
3. No-plastic in interior.

title: Green
promoTeaserSmall: Green
promoTeaser: Green
metaTitle: Green
metaDescription: Green

pageElements.text: There are many ways to be green these days. This category includes cars that get at least 40 mpg. But beyond fuel efficiency, this category includes alternative-fuel or electric vehicles and PLEV, ULEV, and ZLEV category cars.

title: sporty
promoTeaserSmall: sporty
promoTeaser: sporty
metaTitle: sporty
metaDescription: sporty

pageElements.text: Sportiness is like art: you know it when you see it. This category includes roadsters, coupes, and sedans with temptingly low 0-to-60-mph times.  They range from super hot dream cars to the reasonably accessible. You’d have fun in any of them.

title: crossover
promoTeaserSmall: crossover
promoTeaser: crossover
metaTitle: crossover
metaDescription: crossover

pageElements.text: This newest category describes a utility vehicle, but one built on a car platform instead of a truck platform. The crossover has more carlike ride and handling and generally better fuel economy than an SUV, and more space than a station wagon.

title: 2013 Ford F-150
subTitle: So American, you can almost glimpse the purple mountains’ majesty above the fruited plain
metaTitle: 2013 Ford F-150 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ford F-150 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: While the world frets about fuel economy, while sales of small cars increase exponentially, the Ford F-150 soldiers on, even though its best fuel economy number is 23 mpg on the highway. But fuel economy is not the main reason for the F-Series; utility is. Besides, every F-Series truck in the Ford lineup has a six-speed automatic transmission, a fuel saver. Ten kinds of F-150s are available, from the workaday XL to the edgy SVT Raptor to the ultra-gussied-up Harley-Davidson F-150 edition. The Raptor is a “performance truck” with a massive 411 horsepower and off-roading amenities including beadlock-capable wheels to keep the tires in place and heavy-duty skid plates to protect the chassis during heavy-duty driving. Seating inside the F-150s runs the gamut from basic on the XL to snakeskin-accented black leather on the Harley-Davidson edition. SuperCab and SuperCrew versions can bring the total passenger volume to six, while the standard F-150 seats three. Among the amenities are power telescoping and power folding trailer-tow side-view mirrors and a set of high-intensity discharge headlamps. An interesting touch is that climate and audio controls are “optimized” for use by those who may be encumbered by wearing heavy work gloves. The F-150 continues to sell so well because it continues to offer utility and practicality in a user-friendly package.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Silverado
2. GMC Sierra
3. Ram 1500
4. Nissan Titan

Cool Tech:
1. Hill Descent Control for FX4 model.
2. Power telescoping and folding trailer tow sideview mirrors.
3. Optimized controls for glove-wearing workers on Ford Sync system.

Looks
1. Limited model has red-and-black leather interior.
2. Harley-Davidson model has cycle-like black leather seats with snakeskin accents.
3. King Ranch model has ranch-themed badging and interior decor.

New for 2013
1. New front end with HID headlamps.
2. MyFord 4.2-inch multifunction LCD screen.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT
subTitle: The revised name signals more serious intent and new capabilities. Is your wallet up to the challenge?
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The SLS AMG has only been on sale for about a year and a half, but it’s already receiving upgrades to the powertrain as well as new trim inside and out. The hard-edged people at AMG, the performance-oriented subsidiary of Mercedes’s parent Daimler, obviously weren’t satisfied with the 6.3-liter V-8’s output of 563 horsepower -- who would be? -- so they managed to wring another 20 horsepower from it. The seven-speed transmission, which sits on the rear axle, is recalibrated for faster shifting when the manual mode and aluminum paddle shifters are used. The Adaptive Performance Suspension that features variable, electronically-tuned shock absorbers, now is tuned for stiffer springs and shocks, resulting in a more dynamic feel. To mark the new model, which finds “GT” added to the name, the exterior is festooned anew. Special badges denote the GT, and headlight covers and tail light treatments are darker. The brake calipers now wear a fashionable coat of red. And a high-gloss black finish is added to the front grille trim, side mirrors, and the various fins found on the hood and fenders. Inside the car, red seatbelts provide a sporty contrast with newly added black trim on center console and door panels.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competitors:
1. Aston Martin Virage
2. Ferrari California
3. Jaguar XKR-S

Cool Tech Items:
1. The revised adaptive performance suspension features variable, electronically controlled shock absorbers.
2. Adjustable suspension has a “sport plus” mode that’s suitable for the track.
3. Invoking the historic Mercedes-Benz SL300 and easing entry and egress, the coupe’s gullwing doors swing up 70 degrees.

Looks:
1. AMG Designo series swathes the interior in leather and with extra Alcantara trim as well.
2. Carbon-fiber side mirrors are optional.
3. Ten-spoke forged-alloy wheels in a selection of colors are optional.

New for 2013:
1. The 6.2-liter V-8 gains 20 horsepower.
2. Seven-speed transmission is recalibrated.
3. Steering wheel now has Alcantara grips and a flat bottom section.

title: 2013 Honda Fit
subTitle: Like Mary Poppins’ bag or a clown car, the Fit is bigger than it looks
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Honda Fit
promoTeaser: 2013 Honda Fit
metaTitle: 2013 Honda Fit Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Fit Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Fit is a small car, but don’t let that fool you. With just enough room to fit four fully grown adults (or five, if you know an adult who can fit in the back middle seat) it is able to morph into a utility vehicle with the seats down, offering up to 57.3 cubic feet of storage space, more than any of Honda’s sedans or the Crosstour. The Fit accomplishes this with its rear Magic Seat, which folds up like origami paper into four different positions, including a bed-like reclined state. Its small size also helps the Fit achieve Honda’s characteristic strong gas mileage, with 27 to 28 city mpg and 33 to 35 highway mpg. The 117-horsepower engine and five-speed transmission (available as a manual or an automatic) suffers from the lack of a sixth gear, and the suspension can leave you bouncing from time to time, but the Fit is plenty fun to drive, especially with its mileage and cargo space taken into account. With a base price range topping out at $20,000, the Fit lacks interior options, giving it a slightly spartan feel, but with all of the Fit’s other charms, you may not even notice.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Ford Fiesta
3. Toyota Yaris

Cool Tech:
1. Magic Seat offers plenty of options for storage.
2. Thirty-five highway mpg is as good as some hybrids.
3. Class leader in safety.

Look:
1. Looks and acts like a minivan hit with a shrink ray.
2. Comes in fun colors like red and bright blue.

New for 2013:
1. New exterior color: Midnight Plum Pearl (replacing Orange Burst Metallic).

title: 2013 Honda Insight
subTitle: An affordable hybrid that doesn’t feel cheap
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Honda Insight
promoTeaser: 2013 Honda Insight
metaTitle: 2013 Honda Insight Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Insight Buyer's Guide
