pageElements.text: The Insight is yet another hybrid by Honda, and it provides everything we have come to expect from Honda’s green cars. The Insight shares its hybrid technology with the ever-popular Civic Hybrid, and gets similar gas mileage with 41 mpg in the city and 44 mpg on the highway. The Insight melds the interior of several other Honda sedans, creating an appealing Frankenstein’s monster of ergonomic controls.  The interior also offers plenty of hiding spots and storage space for whatever you carry around. Perhaps the Insight’s biggest draw is its price, with a base price below $20,000. The low price isn’t without drawbacks, however, and the Insight can be rough on bumpy roads and loud at high speeds.  Honda didn’t skimp on safety, though, and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety rated the Insight as a Top Safety Pick. With rear seats down the cargo space – already respectable for a small car – almost doubles. The Insight’s charms and price are enough to make up for some minor deficiencies, and it is a good choice if you’re looking for a hybrid that doesn't break the bank.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Fusion Hybrid
2. Hyundai Sonata Hybrid
3. Toyota Camry Hybrid

Cool Tech:
1. Slight design changes in 2012 resulted in even better fuel efficiency.
2. USB and auxiliary input jacks, can play Windows Media Audio.

Looks:
1. Intuitive, streamlined control panel.
2. Sleek exterior with hatchback.

title: 2013 Hyundai Elantra
subTitle: The 2013 Hyundai Elantra lineup is spiced up with the addition of the 2013 Hyundai Elantra GT hatchback, which injects European styling and five-door functionality to the lineup
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Hyundai Elantra
promoTeaser: 2013 Hyundai Elantra
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Elantra Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Hyundai Elantra Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 Hyundai Elantra comes in several flavors, including a sedan, coupe, and a new Elantra GT hatchback that replaces the Elantra Touring. The Elantra, which was named the 2012 North American Car of the Year by a very picky panel of automotive journalists, is one of the best small cars on the market. The Elantra GT offers a sportier ride than the sedan version, along with a roomy cabin. The base Elantra sedan takes a lot of anxiety away at the gas pump, since it returns 40 mpg on the highway. The Elantra GT falls just short of that, delivering 39 mpg on the highway. Standard features on the 2013 Elantra GT include a 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine rated at 148 horsepower, heated front seats, seventeen-inch alloy wheels, and seven airbags. The Elantra GT starts at $19,170, including a $775 destination charge. A GT Style package for both versions of the Elantra GT is priced at $2,750 and adds such items as seventeen-inch alloy wheels, sport-tuned suspension, panoramic sunroof, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and aluminum pedals. A GT Technology package for both versions of the Elantra GT is priced at $2,350 and adds a navigation system, rearview camera, automatic headlights, and dual automatic temperature control. This option requires the Style package, noted Hyundai. If your shopping list includes such mainstays as the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla, you’d be remiss not to take a test drive in the Elantra.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors
1. Toyota Matrix
2. Ford Focus
3. Volkswagen Golf
4. Chevrolet Cruze
5. Honda Civic
6. Mazda3

Cool Tech:
1. Navigation system integrates a rearview camera, an unusual feature in this segment that can’t be found on competitors such as Honda Civic and Mazda3.

New for 2013:
1. Elantra GT model.
2. Base Elantra sedan gets upgrades including air conditioning, cruise control, sixteen-inch steel wheels, telescopic steering wheel.
3. Power driver seat with lumbar support is new standard feature on Elantra Limited.
4. Atlantic Blue is new exterior color.

title: 2013 Jaguar XK
subTitle: Put on your speed suit and drive the Jaguar XK, Catwoman.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Jaguar XK
promoTeaser: 2013 Jaguar XK
metaTitle: 2013 Jaguar XK Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Jaguar XK Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The XK is the product of a match made in Jaguar heaven. Here you’ll find tiny bits of the Jaguar DNA that stole our hearts in the 1961 Jaguar E-type in nuanced, refined curves that cast a diamond-drop silhouette. The 5.0-liter V-8 engine seems to soar, eliciting a staggering 550 horsepower in a choreographed dance with the six-speed automatic transmission. Last year the XK had a minor face lift, lowering its grille and rear fascia. The headlights are slimmer and seem to glimmer as you leave the competition in the dust. Inside, there is a mod touch in the Phosphor blue illumination that highlights the instrument panel. While the XK is the slinkiest of the Jaguars and speaks the design language of a classic British sports car, the XKR-S emphasizes the model’s speedier side with the addition of a sportier front grille and enhanced side panels. The heady XKR-S is the perfect way to experience the giddy feeling of driving this frisky feline as it zooms from 0 to 60 mph in 4.2 seconds. If, by chance, you hear this wild cat roar, don’t run the other way! Only 100 XK coupes and convertibles are available for purchase.
Fun-O-Meter: 9.5

Competitors:
1. Porsche 911 Turbo S
2. Mercedes-Benz SL550
3. BMW 650i

Cool Tech:
1. The leather steering wheel houses interior controls.
2. Dual-zone climate control keeps the atmosphere pleasant.
3. The instrument panel is highlighted with Phosphor blue illumination.

Looks:
1. The XK is the slinkiest of the Jaguars and speaks the design language of a classic British sports car.
2. The XKR-S emphasizes the speedier side of the coin with the addition of a sportier front grille and enhanced side panels.
3. Choose from fifteen wide and varied options for exterior color, veneers, and interior décor.

title: 2013 Jeep Patriot
subTitle: A cheap Jeep, now with desperately needed upgrades
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Jeep Patriot
promoTeaser: 2013 Jeep Patriot
metaTitle: 2013 Jeep Patriot Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Jeep Patriot Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The cheapest Jeep doesn’t get a lot of love from the enthusiast community, but in the past few years Jeep has made a significant effort to improve its small off-roader. The 2013 Patriot is the most fuel-efficient model yet, with a five-speed manual that can reach 30 miles per gallon on the highway. In 2012, improvements to the interior finally made the Patriot competitive in its class, and it even boasts Jeep’s Trail Rated badge. (Don’t take it on the Rubicon, though; the Patriot is still no Wrangler.) The upside of some lackluster components is that the Patriot is by far Jeep’s cheapest option; with a base price of $15,995 it is kind to even the sparsest pocketbooks. The upgraded interior includes deluxe cloth seats, a sound system with MP3 support and an audio jack, and optional Uconnect that can act as a mobile WiFi hotspot for up to eight devices. Like the Compass and the Liberty, the Patriot will be replaced by a new Fiat-based model by 2013 or 2014, so if this budget Jeep is your dream car you may as well get it while the getting is good.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Kia Sportage
2. Mitsubishi Outlander Sport
3. Suzuki SX4

Cool Tech:
1. Available Uconnect can turn car into mobile WiFi hotspot.
2. Available off-roading package.
3. Standard 115-volt outlet powers household appliances.

Looks:
1. Available power sunroof.
2. Available sound system with nine speakers including two flip-down liftgate speakers.
3. Classic Jeep styling.

New for 2013:
1. Two new exterior colors.
2. Improved gas mileage.

title: 2012 Lotus Evora
subTitle: If you want a Lotus this is the one
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Lotus Evora
promoTeaser: 2012 Lotus Evora
metaTitle: 2012 Lotus Evora Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Lotus Evora Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Evora is the only Lotus currently sold in the United States, which makes it the only option for Lotus lovers looking for a new car. The Evora lives up to its racecar pedigree with good starting and stopping power. The interior is sparse but not unattractive, with available contrast stitching and front racing seats. Options include a touchscreen navigation system, a backup camera, and iPod and MP3 connectivity. The area behind the front row can be configured to hold two seats, but the Evora still wouldn’t quite count as a four-seater, earning a 2+2 designation instead. Don’t let that deter you if you’ve got a young family, though. The available back seat comes equipped to handle child seats. If you’re not enticed by a tight squeeze in the back seat, that area can turn into a low bench instead, perfect for hauling shopping bags (though maybe not groceries for five). It gets good gas mileage for a sports car, making almost 30 mpg on the highway, but even the base model is more expensive than most competitors. That said, you won’t be bored behind the wheel of the Evora.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Audi TT RS
2. BMW M3
3. Porsche Cayman

Cool Tech:
1. Available touch screen navigation system.
2. Available iPod and MP3 connectivity.
3. Available backup camera.

Looks:
1. Slightly offbeat but distinctive exterior.
2. Standard front racing seats.
3. Available rear seat.

title: 2013 Suzuki Equator
subTitle: The Equator is here for all your Suzuki-brand towing and stowing needs.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Suzuki Equator
promoTeaser: 2013 Suzuki Equator
metaTitle: 2013 Suzuki Equator Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Suzuki Equator here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Motorcycles and boats are great, but they aren’t always practical. If you drive a Suzuki motorcycle or have a Suzuki outboard motor on your boat, you can transport them using a Suzuki-brand truck. The super-practical 2013 Equator has a towing capacity of up to 6,300 pounds, meaning that you should have little or no trouble pulling your boat out of storage and putting it in the water just before fishing season begins. In addition to this, both the Extended and Crew Cab body styles have flip-up rear seats, fold-down passenger seats, and storage boxes for moving smaller things that either can’t or shouldn’t be hitched to the back of a truck. Suzuki believes in providing its customers with options, so in addition to your choice of cab body styles, you also have the choice of a long or short bed for your Equator, as well as a five-speed manual or automatic transmission. However, keep in mind, stick-shift aficionados, that the manual is only available with the 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine. The automatic only comes with the V-6. For your driving convenience, this pickup truck also features heated leather seats and a sunroof for those sunny but bitter cold winter days.
Fun-O-Meter: 3

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Colorado
2. GMC Canyon
3. Honda Ridgeline
4. Nissan Frontier

Cool Tech Items:
1. Dual power mirrors.
2. Front reading lamp.

Looks:
1. Chrome rear bumper and front grille.
2. UV cut glass and privacy glass.

New for 2013:
1. Three new exterior colors.
2. Larger headrests.
3. Electronic stability control available on all models.

title: 2013 Subaru Outback
subTitle: Subaru offers a safer way to transport everything-and the kitchen sink-in the 2013 Outback.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Subaru Outback
promoTeaser: 2013 Subaru Outback
metaTitle: 2013 Subaru Outback  Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Subaru Outback here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It handles like a car, but it is truly an SUV. Subaru’s 2013 Outback, the world’s original crossover vehicle, offers its passengers all of the capabilities of an SUV with the stability of a sedan, making it an excellent car for both short trips to school or the market and longer family road trips. Featuring an estimated fuel economy of up to 30 mpg highway and a super-quiet ride, you’re not very likely to find a better deal for $24,000-$32,000 amongst the Outback’s competitors.  If you’re the outdoorsy or sporty type, you’ll be particularly taken with the 71.3 cubic feet of cargo space and the adjustable rear roof crossbar, which will allow you to cart a variety of bulky sporting gear with you on your adventures or at least ensure that you have enough room to transport the majority, if not all, of your daughter’s belongings to college without having to leave her behind! The Outback also makes certain that all your trips to campus are safe ones thanks to Subaru’s new EyeSight system, which will activate the breaks before a collision and a stereo camera that will let you see the obstacles in your path before you feel them.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Escape
2. GMC Terrain
3. Jeep Liberty
4. Toyota Highlander

Cool Tech Items:
1. EyeSight driver assist system.
2. Harman/Kardon audio system (on the Premium model).

Looks:
1. Ground clearance of 8.7 inches.
2. Redesigned grille, headlights, and bumper cover.

New for 2013:
1. New engine with more power.
2. Bluetooth steering wheel control switches.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class
subTitle: If you can’t find the right shape or features and then have fun with it, your meds aren’t working
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: There’s always the secure feeling that comes from being in a well-built car. Which car, exactly? Try the E-Class coupe, convertible, sedan, or station wagon. Here’s the thing about the E-Class: it’s the anchor of the whole Mercedes-Benz brand. They sell it in every body style except one that can fly off and rescue mountaineers. It wouldn’t have surprised us if James Cameron found an E-Class when he took his Deepsea Challenger to the bottom of the Pacific. An interesting thing has happened with the E-Class since the ninth generation model appeared in 2010. It got sportier and more rewarding to drive. Now, as few as four or as many as seven people can climb inside. In addition to the E350’s punchy 3.5-liter V-6, the order sheet includes a strong and efficient turbo-diesel V-6 and a cyclonic pair of turbocharged V-8s. New to the lineup is the E400 Hybrid, which combines the gasoline-fed V-6 making 302 horsepower with an electric motor that allows for some electric-only maneuvering and assists the gas engine once under way. Also new as standard features in the coupe and convertible are heated front seats and the latest-generation mbrace telematics software. A seven-speed automatic transmission serves in all E-Class forms.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi A6
2. BMW 5-series
3. Infiniti M

Cool Tech:
1. Convertible includes Aircap deflector that automatically rises from the windshield header to diminish turbulence.
2. Convertible’s optional Airscarf is neck-level heating vents integrated into the front seats.
3. Automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver lets off the brake.

Looks:
1. E550 coupe and convertible roll on eighteen-inch five-twin-spoke AMG wheels.
2. Larger, eighteen-inch five-spoke wheels come with the E350 coupe and convertible.
3. Sport sedans have three-bar grille while luxury sedans have four bars.

New for 2013
1. Coupe and convertible have electromechanical steering for 2013 and all-wheel drive is available in the coupe.
2. Heated front seats are standard in the coupe and convertible.
3. E63 AMG sedan now comes with Premium 2 package standard.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class
subTitle: With so many SUVs in the lineup, the ML has the odd effect of pointing back toward the E-Class station wagon
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class Buyer's Guide. With so many SUVs in the lineup, the ML has the odd effect of pointing back toward the E-Class station wagon.

pageElements.text: The ML-Class SUVs are tall and heavy, so their handling on the road is mediocre. The ML350 BlueTec 4Matic’s turbo-diesel lags before delivering its low-end power and then wheezes when pushed hard. The exterior design is cluttered and derivative, as though mighty Mercedes has been looking over its shoulder at the Koreans. Inside, there’s only seating for five. The optional On- and Off-Road Package offers a two-speed transfer case, locking center differential for crawling ability, and six transmission settings, all of which will significantly reduce the difficulty of your trek to drop off kids at the junior high school. (Maybe this redundant capability explains why a simple rear-wheel-drive version of the ML350 is now offered.) Mercedes piles on the standard features with the latest “mbrace” telematics system to link with your smartphone, an anti-collision system, and a colorful new instrument panel. In case you don’t want to wait until you reach the resort to get a massage, the optional contoured seats will give you one. (If it’s a hot-stone treatment, though, see your dealer.) Yes, there are turbocharged V-8 versions of the ML. But what we want to know is, if you seek a Mercedes with utility, why not look at the E-Class station wagon instead?
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Acura MDX
2. Jeep Grand Cherokee
3. BMW X5

Cool Tech:
1. Anti-collision system is new for 2013.
2. Two-stage transfer case with differential lock and six transmission settings is available.
3. A rear-seat iPad docking station is available.

Looks
1. Upholstered dashboard is now standard in the ML550 4Matic.
2. Multicolor ambient lighting and illuminated front door sills are available.
3. Twenty-one-inch wheels are available with the ML63 AMG.

New for 2013
1. Rear-wheel-drive ML350 joins the lineup.
2. Sculpted front seats with massage feature are optional.
3. Latest mbrace telematics system.

title: 2012 Scion iQ
subTitle: Smarter than a Smart Car
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Scion iQ
promoTeaser: 2012 Scion iQ
metaTitle: 2012 Scion iQ Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Scion iQ here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: At first glance, it’s easy to mistake the Scion iQ for the Smart ForTwo. Both are tiny city cars with high gas mileage and relatively few practical uses outside the urban center. The iQ has improved upon some of Smart’s drawbacks, however, and has the dubious honor of being the smallest four-passenger car for sale in the United States. The iQ is often marketed as a 3+1 car instead of a four-seater, because the front driver’s seat is positioned further back than the passenger seat, eating up much of the rear legroom on that side. The Scion earns essentially the same gas mileage as the Smart, with 36 mpg in the city and 37 on the highway, but where it really shows its advantage is in the ride. Despite its short wheelbase, the iQ doesn’t jostle you over every bump in the road. It is also extremely maneuverable, with a turning radius almost three feet shorter than the Smart’s. If you’re looking for an ultracompact car with a little more legroom, the Fiat 500 is a safer bet, but the iQ has the rest of the bases covered.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competition:
1. Smart ForTwo
2. Fiat 500
3. Mini Cooper

Cool Tech:
1. Standard Bluetooth and HD radio.
2. Available touchscreen audio system with iPhone connectivity.
3. Rear seats fold flat for more cargo space.

Looks:
1. Available in bright colors.
2. Spartan center console avoids cluttering small space.
3. Contrast stitching on steering wheel and shifter.

title: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman
subTitle: Good things come in big(ger) packages.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman
promoTeaser: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman
metaTitle: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mini Countryman doesn’t enter production until November of 2012, but that doesn’t mean you can’t lust after it now. With so much extra space (the Countryman is a whole eighteen inches longer than its brethren) that you can hardly call it mini, the Countryman does a fine job accommodating four people.  The 2012 model reaches up to 35 miles to the gallon on the highway, but the Countryman still offers the performance you expect from a Mini, and has the distinction of being the only car in Mini’s lineup to come with available four-wheel drive. Despite its slightly bulkier body, the Countryman is unmistakable as a Mini. It has an aggressive forward stance and quasi-retro styling, and while the interior styling could be a little sleeker, it is undeniably fun. A center rail that runs the length of the car has colored ambient lighting and sliding rear cup holders. The black dashboard and seats can be accented with a variety of colors including bright red and blue, and the large center-mounted speedometer adds quirk – though it does have the drawback of letting passengers keep tabs on your lead foot.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Honda CR-V
2. Nissan Juke
3. Volkswagen Tiguan

Cool Tech:
1. Available navigation system mounted in over-sized speedometer.
2. Available rear Park Distance Control.
3. Standard HD radio.

Looks:
1. Available bonnet stripes in white or black.
2. Center rail with ambient lighting.
3. Dozens of possible color combinations.

New for 2013:
1. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.
2. New John Cooper Works trim level.
3. Available turbocharged engine.

title: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer
subTitle: With so many options on the 2013 Lancer, you get a near-custom car for a reasonable price
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer
promoTeaser: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer
metaTitle: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The racing-inspired Lancer Evolution has definitely been a favorite in years past, but Mitsubishi has left it as is for the 2013 model year in favor of updating some of the other Lancer trim levels that appeal to a more money-conscious drivers. Now, all-wheel drive is no longer exclusive to the Evolution, but a standard feature on the Ralliart. In fact, many cosmetic features that would generally be bundled in a package, like exterior-matching door handles and mirrors, and interior chrome trim come standard on the many of the trim levels, as do power windows, mirrors, and doors. If that sort of thing isn’t important to you, you’ll be pleased to hear that nearly all safety and security features are standard on all models, making every trim level a safe purchase. With Electric Power Steering, a continuously variable transmission, and a 2.0-liter 4-cylinder engine, the Lancer receives up to 26 mpg city and 34 mpg highway, but don’t expect a quiet ride to go along with the mileage. The Lancer is definitely a fun car to drive and a smart buy, but wind and road noise will be considerable for those who intend to use the car for normal driving rather than amateur racing.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Honda Civic/Si
2. Ford Focus/ST
3. Subaru Impreza/WRX
4. Volkswagen Golf/GTI/R

Cool Tech:
1. Intelligent & Innovative Vehicle Electronic Control system.
2. Six-speed automated manual Twin-Clutch Sportronic Shift Transmission.

Looks:
1. Redesigned alloy wheels.
2. Blacked-out front grille.

New for 2013:
1. Cosmic Blue exterior paint.
2. Plug-in roof carrier.

title: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport
subTitle: A far cry from its larger, sedate cousin the Outlander, the Outlander Sport makes driving a colorful adventure for 2013
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport
promoTeaser: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport
metaTitle: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: There’s a reason why the Outlander Sport is Mitsubishi’s best-selling vehicle in North America. With its sticker price of only $19,170, combined mileage of 27 mpg, and ability to seat five adults comfortably, the Outlander Sport is a great car for someone who wants an affordable sport-utility vehicle. The car comes with one engine, a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, but you have the choice of a five-speed manual or a continuously variable transmission (CVT). For the 2013 model year, the Outlander Sport has been redesigned both inside and out with new bumper designs and wheels, as well as new interior fabrics and chrome accents. When you head out to the dealerships, you’ll see the car in two new colors, but you’ll find that it’s particularly eye-catching in Laguna Blue. No matter where you live, we promise that having a cerulean blue car parked in the driveway will make your house look like a tropical getaway! If you like bells, whistles, and tons of lights, you have the option of purchase a wide array of packages to customize your car. The most fun packages are the LED Illumination and Premium packages, which add floor illumination and a panoramic glass roof with mood lighting to make your evening drives a bit more magical.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Hyundai Santa Fe
2. Kia Sportage
3. Mini Countryman
4. Nissan Juke

Cool Tech:
1. HDD navigation system with real-time traffic.
2. Electric Power Steering.
3. Dent-resistant polymer front fenders.

Looks:
1. Panoramic glass roof.
2. Eighteen-inch alloy wheels on all trim levels.

New for 2013
1. Higher grade insulation material for noise reduction.
2. New speakers for better sound.
3. New fabrics for seats.
4. Two-tone exterior color scheme.
5. Two new exterior paint colors: White Pearl and Quick Silver.

title: What Car Seat When?
promoTeaserSmall: Yes, your eight-year-old still needs a car seat. Time to play the Because I Said So card.
promoTeaser: Yes, your eight-year-old still needs a car seat. Time to play the Because I Said So card.
metaTitle: What Car Seat When?
metaDescription: Jean Knows Cars helps you figure out what car seat is right for children at different ages and sizes.

pageElements.text: Maybe I should be putting this on the Confessions page of Jean Knows Cars, but back in the day, I often broke an essential car safety rule with my own children. I let my kids ride in cars without using booster seats before the recommended age and height. Call it peer pressure; none of their friends were still in booster seats. They’re teenagers now, but if I had it to do over again, I would keep them all in boosters until they were four feet, nine inches tall. That’s the size where seatbelts fit properly without a booster--and especially now that air bags are everywhere, it’s the size at which a deploying bag won’t potentially endanger a child who is sitting too low in the vehicle.  Hey, there was a time when nobody used a bike helmet. Now, they’re ubiquitous. We parents need to make booster seats universal in that same way.

images.caption: The ages and stages of child seats, spelled out for you.
Rear facing: not just for infants anymore (Britax B-Safe).
Convertible seat, with five-point harness (Britax Boulevard).
Booster seats are a must until four feet nine (Graco TurboBoosters).

pageElements.text:
Three Stages to the Child Seat Journey

With this story, you'll find a chart showing you the guidelines about child seat use. Notice that it says:
    You need to keep your child facing toward the rear as long as possible. That could be as old as age three, depending on your child's height and weight. It should definitely be until age two.
    Once your child is facing forward, he or she needs to be in a forward-facing child seat for as long as possible before switching to a booster. That means, until that child has honestly outgrown the seat by height and his or her head is sticking above the seatback.
    Then your child, who by now is in mid- to late elementary school, is ready for a belt-positioning booster seat. There are a recent crop of these on the market that are colorful, easy to use, and will position your child so that the seatbelt rests across the upper thighs, not all the way up on his or her stomach, and fits snugly across the shoulder and chest, never behind the back or under the armpit.

Age Twelve, In Booster? Yup!

It's not until a child is at least four feet, nine inches tall that he or she can safely ride in the car without a booster seat. Yes, that means there are twelve-year-olds out there who ought to be in booster seats. Lots of them. And, no matter how much they want to, children under age twelve need to ride in the back seat. It's a safer place in the event of an accident, not to mention that it's more peaceful and easier for you as the driver to concentrate if your kids are in their own zone while you drive.

The federal government maintains an online list of child seat ratings. This ratings list grades specific seats on their ease of use. Use it, and save yourself some trouble in everyday car travel with your child.

title: 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye
promoTeaserSmall: Italian engine meets classic American car
promoTeaser: Italian engine meets classic American car
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out Jean Jennings' review of the 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye here on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye has the name and thus the heritage of the classic Dart from the Sixties and Seventies. However, it has a very Italian MultiAir turbo engine under its hood, and it also looks very different from the old Dart. This marks Dodge's return to the compact sedan segment that it has been out of since it stopped making the Neon in 2005.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/9BROCPdfSlQ?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It's also Dodge's way of tapping into retro nostalgia for what was a much loved American nameplate, back in the day. The new Dart shares a platform with Fiat's Alfa Romeo brand, in addition to that engine, and a bonus there is that they are very good with small engine technology.

Standard safety features include anti-lock brakes, traction control, brake assist, and ten air bags, including front and side curtain, driver's-side inflatable knee, and passenger's side inflatable knee bolster bags.

The Dart's competition will be the Toyota Corolla, Chevrolet Cruze, and Hyundai Elantra GLS. The Elantra hits the magic 40-mpg mark, but the Dart doesn't, although it comes close -- topping out at 39 mpg on the highway with the 1.4-liter four-cylinder engine with six-speed manual transmission.

title: 2013 Mazda CX-9
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda CX-9, the Japanese automaker’s biggest and perhaps best vehicle, gets a facelift for the new model year.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Mazda CX-9, the Japanese automaker’s biggest and perhaps best vehicle, gets a facelift for the new model year.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Mazda CX-9, the Japanese automaker’s biggest and perhaps best vehicle, gets a facelift for the new model year.
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda CX-9 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda CX-9 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mazda CX-9 gets a makeover for the new model year and now bears a greater family resemblance to the redesigned 2014 Madza 6, which is now poised to be one of the style leaders in the midsize sedan segment. The new look is a welcome change for the CX-9, which hasn’t been tweaked since 2009. The CX-9, which goes on sale late this fall, also gets several new safety features, including forward obstruction warning, lane departure warning, and a high-beam headlight control system. The big Mazda crossover will be equipped with the carryover 273-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine and six-speed automatic transmission. Gas mileage in the CX-9 is so-so. The CX-9 returns 17 mpg in city driving and 24 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The CX-9 has big shoes to fill in the Mazda lineup, especially since it’s the end of the road for the Mazda CX-7, which slotted in below the CX-9. The CX-7 is being discontinued in the U.S. Pricing has yet to be announced for the redone CX-9, but it should start at around $30,000. The CX-9 has always won compliments for its communicative steering, car-like responses, and highway stability, along with good interior quality. The third row may be best left for kids, but the CX-9 is set to remain a more stylish alternative to traditional vans and boxier SUVs.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Buick Enclave
2. Chevrolet Traverse
3. Honda Pilot
4. Toyota Highlander

Cool Tech:
1. Forward obstruction warning and high-beam headlight control system are both unusual in this segment.

New for 2013:
1. Revised exterior patterned after 2013 Mazda 6.
2. New safety features, including forward obstruction warning, lane departure warning, and a high-beam headlight control system.

title: 2013 Lincoln MKS
subTitle: Latest generation of Lincoln’s flagship is as sleek and smooth as you’re expecting.
promoTeaserSmall: Latest generation of Lincoln’s flagship is as sleek and smooth as you’re expecting.
promoTeaser: Latest generation of Lincoln’s flagship is as sleek and smooth as you’re expecting.
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln MKS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lincoln MKS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Its split-grille face may say Voldemort, but its ride is Nimbus 2000 all the way. The 2013 MKS is a redesigned model that holds on to the smooth, refined ride a Lincoln buyer is looking for while adding lots of high-tech features. Chief among those is Lincoln Drive Control, a system that will let you change almost everything about the driving experience by changing the gear selector between Drive and Sport settings. Smoothness, however, is the main point of this car, as underlined by standard Continuously Controlled Damping, which monitors suspension settings 500 times per second and adjusts the suspension twenty times per second to tweak ride quality. While you’re enjoying that ride, there’s also a new lane keeping system that can warn you of potential accidents by making the steering wheel vibrate. What’s more, it’s customizable as to when alerts are sent and how hard they make the steering wheel vibrate. The MKS’s V-6 engine choices are slightly more powerful this year, with the most fuel-efficient choice being the 3.7-liter V-6 that makes 304 horsepower and provides 18 mpg in town and 27 mpg on the highway. An EcoBoost V-6 on the all-wheel-drive MKS ups horsepower to 365, although it offers slightly lower fuel economy at 17 mpg city and 25 mpg highway. The MKS’s looks are dominated by the new split grille, but updates have also been made to the fenders, headlamps, deck lid, rear end, and exhaust tips. The interior has an all-new instrument panel with MyLincoln Touch, an expanded Sync setup, and many new color schemes. Pricing range from $43,685 for the standard model to $50,685 for the EcoBoost model, including destination.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi A6
2. Infiniti M
3. Lexus GS
4. Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Lane keeping technology is, as Lincoln puts it, an extra “eye” on the road.
2. Lincoln Drive Control with Drive and Sport settings.

Looks:
1. Fresh exterior color schemes: Ginger Ale, Kodiak Brown metallic tri-coat, and Ruby Red and Smoked Quartz metallic clearcoat.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Volt
subTitle: Bzzzt! The long-awaited Volt is now a standard member of the automotive mainstream.
promoTeaserSmall: Bzzzt! The long-awaited Volt is now a standard member of the automotive mainstream.
promoTeaser: Bzzzt! The long-awaited Volt is now a standard member of the automotive mainstream.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Volt Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Chevrolet Volt: Learn more about the 2013 model of GM's groundbreaking hybrid. The details are at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Chevrolet’s Volt five-door hatchback EV, so long in the making and so eagerly awaited only a few years ago, is now in its second model year and has become a solid, if less than captivating, citizen in the Chevrolet lineup.  Yes, it runs only thirty-eight miles on electric power alone—which is three miles more than last year’s model—and its rear seat is best suited for children, but consider the fuel economy: 98 mpg equivalent, in the EPA’s parlance for electric vehicles. The range-anxious will appreciate a new Hold Drive mode—added to the Volt’s Normal, Sport, and Mountain drive modes—which helps conserve battery life. On gasoline-only power, fuel economy is 37 mpg. Its fuel economy is aided by a set of Goodyear Fuel Max low-rolling-resistance tires, but they don’t appreciably hurt the ride quality. The Volt will hit a top speed of 100 mph—perhaps not the consideration uppermost on Volt buyers’ minds, but still—and, probably a number more of interest, it has a ten-to-sixteen-hour recharge time using standard household current.  Option packages add such amenities as heated front seats, perforated leather seating and steering wheel, a rear-view camera, and parking sensors at front and back. Lane departure warning and forward collision alert are other options, as is Chevrolet’s MyLink system with navigation. All that, and a range between fillups of 382 miles, if you take both the battery life and the fuel tank’s capacity into account.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Nissan Leaf
2. Toyota Prius

Cool Tech Items:
1. Hold Drive mode to help conserve the battery.

Looks:
1. Perforated leather seating and steering wheel.
2. Body-color roof and liftgate.
3. Pebble Beige color cloth or leather seating new for 2013.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Spark
subTitle: Mini Chevy is cute, cute, cute, but its fuel economy is not as big as it is small.
promoTeaserSmall: Mini Chevy is cute, cute, cute, but its fuel economy is not as big as it is small.
promoTeaser: Mini Chevy is cute, cute, cute, but its fuel economy is not as big as it is small.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Spark Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Spark here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s a car for a small planet: the Chevrolet Spark is tiny and adorable. It also has a five-door hatchback body style with a reasonably sized back seat area, making it an unusual choice in the minicar category. Priced starting at just under $13,000, it’s a logical alternative to cars like the Fiat 500. Unfortunately, the Spark doesn’t astonish with great fuel economy: it makes 28 to 32 mpg in town and tops out at 38 mpg on the highway. Since 40 mpg has become the number to beat, that’s not a brilliant figure, especially considering the Spark only offers 84 horsepower from a 1.2-liter four-cylinder engine. Five-speed manual and four-speed automatic transmissions are available, and despite its diminutive size, the Spark has a grown-up set of ten standard airbags. Chevrolet is aiming this, its first U.S.-market minicar, at city dwellers, which explains in part why it offers MyLink information and entertainment with a seven-inch color screen, Bluetooth streaming audio, and Pandora and Stitcher compatibility. It may not be the greenest of the small cars, but it’s a pretty colorful choice for a starter car.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Fiat 500
2. Scion iQ
3. Smart ForTwo

Cool Tech Items:
1. MyLink Radio with seven-inch color touchscreen.
2. BringGo embedded GPS navigation app (late availability).

Looks:
1. Five-door body looks like a three-door because door handles are integrated into the C-pillar area.
2. Salsa Red, Jalapeno, Denim, Lemonade (late availability) and Techno Pink are among the color choices.

New for 2013:
1. New model for U.S. and Canada.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu
subTitle: All-new model, available in hybrid or traditional four-cylinder flavors.
promoTeaserSmall: All-new model, available in hybrid or traditional four-cylinder flavors.
promoTeaser: All-new model, available in hybrid or traditional four-cylinder flavors.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Chevrolet completely redid the Malibu for 2013, giving it a more modern appearance, widening it for more interior room and trunk space, and going with the ecological flow by offering it as a hybrid. This mid-size sedan is available either as a four-cylinder/electric hybrid or with a standard or turbocharged four-cylinder engine, all of which are paired with a fuel-friendly six-speed automatic transmission. The hybrid version, called the Malibu Eco, has General Motors’ eAssist lithium-ion battery setup, giving the sedan a 37-mpg highway fuel economy rating. That’s impressive, but not the best you can do in today’s eco-competitive marketplace. The Eco model has been dressed up with metallic, chrome, or wood accents in the cockpit, plus ice blue ambient lighting and—surprise—a swiveling radio face that hides a six-inch-deep secret storage compartment. Chevrolet calls this “the quietest Chevrolet in history,” asking you to notice its use of sound-reducing and sound-absorbing materials inside the Malibu. While you’re enjoying the quiet, note the trendy dual cockpit and the presence of the Chevrolet MyLink information and entertainment system, standard on the Eco model. Even General Motors admits that the mid-size sedan segment is “vanilla,” but the company has worked hard to position the Malibu, now in its eighth generation, as a modern contender.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Honda Accord
2. Hyundai Sonata
3. Toyota Camry
4. Volkswagen Passat

Cool Tech Items:
1. Eco model has eAssist, GM’s lithium-ion battery system.
2. Regenerative braking with Eco model provides up to fifteen kilowatts of energy to charge battery.

Looks:
1. Dual cockpit not to everybody’s taste, but different.
2. “Powerdome” hood a little aggressive for a mid-size sedan!

New for 2013:
1. All-new four-cylinder engine.
2. More aerodynamically correct body style.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Equinox
subTitle: Another crossover that’s not really just another crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: Another crossover that’s not really just another crossover.
promoTeaser: Another crossover that’s not really just another crossover.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Equinox Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Equinox here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s hard to remember a time when crossovers weren’t all over American roads; they have become so well established that it’s harder to notice them or tell them apart. This one is no exception; it gets a more powerful V-6 engine for 2013, without losing out on fuel economy—24 mpg on the highway—but otherwise it’s the tried-and-true smaller crossover that it has been for several years already. The interior is dependable and modern-looking, with blue ambient lighting and a wraparound dashboard with an upright center stack. The exterior has a sleek front end; its raked windshield and sweeping headlamps turn the Equinox into the anti-box. The base four-cylinder engine is no powerhouse, but it can get 32 mpg on the highway if you use the transmission-adjusting Eco mode. For those who want to use their crossover for towing, or just want more power, the newly added 3.6-liter V-6 makes 301 horsepower while adding 37 horsepower over last year’s smaller V-6 engine and, as previously mentioned, with no loss in fuel economy. This front-wheel-drive five-seater may not break any new ground in style or substance, but it is a good choice for anyone seeking a moderate amount of both attractiveness and versatility in a reasonably priced package.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Escape
2. Honda CR-V
3. Hyundai Santa Fe
4. Toyota RAV4

Cool Tech:
1. Eco mode on four-cylinder engine.
2. Lane departure warning system (option on top LTZ model).
3. New suspension package for model with 3.6-liter V-6 engine.

Looks:
1. Power liftgate.
2. New Champagne Silver Metallic exterior color coming later in model year.

New for 2013:
1. FE2 suspension to go with new, larger V-6 engine.

title: 2013 Lincoln MKX
subTitle: Ultramodern crossover won’t short you on comfort or amenities.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Lincoln MKX
promoTeaser: 2013 Lincoln MKX
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln MKX--Buyer's Guide -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Lincoln MKX in the Buyer's Guide of JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: For those who are looking for a practical vehicle, but not too practical, the MKX could be just right. Available in front- and all-wheel-drive versions, this luxurious crossover is priced starting just under $40,000, has a raft of up-to-date technology, and is powered by a 305-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 to get those groceries home while enjoying yourself immensely. Fuel economy is okay but not brilliant, at 19 mpg in town and 26 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive version. The MKX has a wood-accented interior and an optional panoramic Vista Roof, which means you can adjust the sunroof in front while the moonroof in back remains fixed. There are dual power sunshades to go with all that opening to the sky. Technologically, there’s an expanded version of Ford Sync that includes WiFi hotspot capability and standard Operator Assist. Curve control, part of the MKX’s AdvanceTrac stability control system, helps keep you in control when taking fast curves. Optional technology includes collision warning with brake support, which uses radar to identify things you may be in danger of hitting. All that, and this is an attractive crossover, too. The aggressive dual grille may not be to everyone’s taste, but it is definitely distinctive.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi Q5
2. Cadillac SRX
3. Lexus RX

Cool Tech:
1. Curve control.
2. Sync with WiFi hotspot capability.

Looks:
1. Coming soon: twenty-two-inch polished aluminum wheels.
2. Four new exterior colors for 2013, including Ginger Ale, Ruby Red and Smoked Quartz metallic clearcoats, and Kodiak Brown metallic tri-coat.

title: 2013 Mazda 6 at the Paris Auto Show
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda 6, as I saw it in Paris: a sportier alternative to mainstream sedans.
promoTitle: 2013 Mazda 6 at the Paris Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mazda 6
promoTeaser: 2013 Mazda 6
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda 6 in Paris -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: See the 2013 Mazda 6 unveiled at the Paris Auto Show. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/fQJ6zZWskz8?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Mazda 6 has always been an excellent choice if you’re the type of person who cringes when you see another person wearing the same dress that you have on at a party. With the Japanese midsize sedan, you won’t see yourself coming and going on the road like you will with some of the domestic competition. Mazda is in somewhat of a holding pattern with the Mazda 6 at this point, since a fully redesigned model is on tap for the 2014 model year. In the meantime, there are no significant changes to the Mazda 6. The current generation sedan has a striking presence, with a long hood and flared front fenders. Mazda pitches it as being “sexy, yet sensible.” The base car is nicely equipped with standard air conditioning, power accessories, cruise control and a stereo system with six speakers. The base Mazda 6 is equipped with a 170-horsepower 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine linked to a six-speed manual transmission. The top-of-the-line model gets a 272-horsepower 3.7-liter V6 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. There are numerous options, including a rear spoiler, remote engine start on automatic-transmission models, pearl exterior paint and a power moonroof. A $1,785 technology package bundles several items, including LED rear lights, heated side mirrors and a power front passenger’s seat. On the downside, there is no hybrid option as there is with some of the competition.

title: 2013 Land Rover LR4
subTitle: The 2013 Land Rover LR4: British Cachet, Rugged Capability
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Land Rover LR4
promoTeaser: 2013 Land Rover LR4
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover LR4--Buyer's Guide--JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Land Rover LR4 in the Buyer's Guide at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Land Rover LR4 is one of the most capable off-roaders on the market, plus it has lots of British cachet to recommend it. But its relatively high price and lousy fuel economy – plus the fact that it requires premium fuel – may turn off some buyers. Parent Jaguar Land Rover has not announced any changes for 2013, but there aren’t likely to be many since the SUV underwent a major renovation in 2010. The LR4 gets a 375-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. It’s an extremely trustworthy and burly beast that can tackle snow, sand, water, or mud with ease. It has four-wheel drive and a truck-based frame and is not a practical choice if you’re just going to take it to the mall and use it for the school car pool. Off-highway driving is where it shows its mettle, thanks to an adjustable air suspension and a fancy Terrain Response system. On the plus side, it costs less than a Range Rover. The LR4 is offered with an optional third row that boosts seating capacity to seven. You can load up the LR4 with lots of amenities, including an optional third-row bench that folds into the floor and an optional rear-seat entertainment system.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Acura MDX
2. BMW X5
3. Cadillac Escalade
4. Volkswagen Touareg

Cool Tech:
1. Terrain Response system, which tailors vehicle characteristics to accommodate driving conditions.

New for 2013:
1. Two new packages: black design package and extended leather package.
2. Five new exterior paint colors.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Sonic
subTitle: Don’t let its small size and cute appearance fool you: this car is not bad at all.
promoTeaserSmall: Don’t let its small size and cute appearance fool you: this car is not bad at all.
promoTeaser: Don’t let its small size and cute appearance fool you: this car is not bad at all.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Sonic Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Sonic here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Sometimes you shop for a subcompact because you’re looking for a cute first car or a nimble city transporter. Sometimes you are motivated by concern about fuel economy and a small carbon footprint. And sometimes you are just plain too broke to buy anything bigger. Don’t feel deprived: the Chevrolet Sonic is actually pretty good. Available in both sedan and hatchback body styles, the U.S.-built Sonic weighs a pretty imposing 2,600 pounds and has ten standard airbags, so it’s no lightweight either literally or figuratively. Its four-cylinder engine choices are the same as those on the larger Cruze. There’s also a turbocharged RS sport hatchback, new this year, which will go on sale in late 2012. The RS’s sportiness is telegraphed by four-wheel disc brakes, a lowered ride height, more assertive chassis and transmission setups, and a leather-trimmed interior, plus red accents and aluminum pedals. You could actually plan to carry back-seat passengers without apologizing, thanks to a relatively roomy interior. An optional Connectivity and Cruise package adds a USB port, Bluetooth audio, steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, and cruise control, and Chevrolet’s MyLink information and entertainment system is available on the uplevel LTZ model and the RS. All in all, you are sure to feel less penalized than you might have expected.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Fiesta
2. Hyundai Accent
3. Kia Rio
4. Nissan Versa

Cool Tech Items:
1.“Three wet” paint process is water based, helping the environment.
2. MyLink for Sonic is an easy-to-use smartphone integrator; standard on RS and LTZ, optional on lower-end LS and LT.

Looks:
1. Sunroof, even though it’s a subcompact.
2. Rear deck-lid spoiler an option on LT, standard on LTZ.

New for 2013:
1. RS sport hatchback.

title: 2012 Lexus LFA
subTitle: An enigmatic, exotic, and exceedingly expensive exception to Lexus’ every rule
promoTeaserSmall: An enigmatic, exotic, and exceedingly expensive exception to Lexus’ every rule
promoTeaser: An enigmatic, exotic, and exceedingly expensive exception to Lexus’ every rule
metaTitle: 2012 Lexus LFA Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Lexus LFA here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: We’re not sure what Lexus product planners were smoking when they came up with the idea to take on Ferrari with its limited-production, 553-horsepower LFA supercar, but we sort of hope they find some more (and share it with some other brands while they’re at it). A true feast for the eyes, the LFA’s coupe-gone-wild styling is highlighted by massive air ducts and grilles all over the car, exquisite details like arrow-themed headlamps and spear-like boomerang-shaped taillamps, and a trio of exhaust pipes in the middle of the rear bumper. But the LFA’s wild styling only hints at the unbelievable experience that awaits any one lucky enough to slip behind the wheel on a long stretch of open road. The purpose-built V-10 rivals any Italian supercar in its thrust and song, while the steering serves up road feel as if on a silver platter. Two racing-style seats are all that fit in the LFA’s sexalicious interior and reconfigurable LCD gauges are truly state-of-the-art. Certainly, we’ll see that technology pop up on other Lexus models in the future, hopefully on vehicles less costly than the LFA, which Lexus brazenly slapped with a base price of $375K. For that coin, exclusivity also comes standard: production has been capped at 500 for the world, all sold as 2012 models. So why is this car listed in a 2013 buyer’s guide? At the time of this writing, Lexus said that a few may still be available.
Fun-O-Meter: 12

Competitors:
1. Ferrari 12 Berlinetta
2. Porsche 911 GT2
3. Aston Martin Vanquish

Cool Tech Items:
1. Everything.

Looks:
1. Everything.

title: 2013 Lexus RX350/RX450h
subTitle: Popularity has never looked so good: Lexus gives its best-selling RX crossover a facelift
promoTeaserSmall: Popularity has never looked so good: Lexus gives its best-selling RX crossover a facelift
promoTeaser: Popularity has never looked so good: Lexus gives its best-selling RX crossover a facelift
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus RX350/RX450h Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus RX350/RX450h here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Luxury crossovers have been all the rage for years now, and none has been found in as many manicured driveways and portes cochères as Lexus’ RX. As a crossover and not a trucky SUV, and with only two rows of seats and not three (like Lexus’s other two luxury utes), the RX is spacious but not excessive, capable but not corpulent, comfortable but not conspicuously consumptive. In other words, for most moderately well-to-do households with a kid or two and a dog, it is just right. Now in the middle of its product cycle, Lexus has seen fit to give its popular RX a thorough face-lift, blessing the mug with the company’s new hourglass-shaped grille and LED daytime running lamp spears, complimented by new taillamps and tailgate details. The interior is slightly upgraded with some new color and trim choices and added technology such as Bluetooth connectivity and Lexus’s new Enform suite of in-car apps, including Pandora, Bing, Facebook, and more. With driving dynamics about as benign as your great aunt Matilda, the RX has never been too exciting to drive, though a new-for-2013 F-Sport model livens things up with its tightened suspension and paddle-shifted eight-speed transmission. And of course, the hybrid RX model (which, as Lexus proudly reminds us, was the industry’s first hybrid SUV) receives the same styling and interior enhancements as the standard model with considerably better fuel economy (30 mpg versus 21 mpg combined), albeit at a steep $6,600 premium. At least a laundry list of safety features come standard on all, most notably ten air bags, including knee airbags for the driver and front passenger.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Cadillac SRX
2. Volvo XC60
3. Lincoln MKX

Cool Tech Items:
1. Pre-collision system with radar cruise control.
2. Available heads-up instrument display on windshield.
3. Available navigation system with “Remote Touch” interface and Lexus Enform apps.

Looks:
1. Styling synced with other recently updated Lexuses.
2. Sport appearance package with nineteen-inch wheels, unique front bumper.
3. Contrast stitching on seats, console and armrests.

New for 2013:
1. LED daytime running lamps and taillamps.
2. F-Sport model with eight-speed transmission, paddle shifters, and sport suspension.
3. Upgraded interior with saddle leather and black bird’s-eye maple optional.
4. Power liftgate.
5. Four new exterior colors.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

relatedArticles.name: article0
relatedArticles.promoTeaser: There's nothing like necessity to focus your thoughts. Don't try this at home.
relatedArticles.title: How I Learned to Drive a Stick Shift

pageElements.text: The first time I drove a stick was on Christmas Day, the winter after I got my driver’s license. I had decided that I wanted to learn how to drive a manual, probably because I wanted an excuse to drive my parents’ cars, which were much nicer than mine. My first session was fine, but not great. I was in my mom’s Saab 9-5, and I didn’t make it out of the parking lot, but I also didn’t destroy the car’s transmission.

A few days later, I tried again in my dad’s Subaru WRX. He had warned me that this transmission would be more difficult than the Saab’s, but I am rarely put off by warnings of that type. He was right, of course, and after spending an hour or so failing to get the car in gear while it bucked wildly around the parking lot, we gave up (him because he was afraid I was breaking his car, and me because I was crying a lot). I still regard that day as a resounding failure, but I did get the best piece of advice I’ve ever gotten about driving a manual when my father suggested I should let out the clutch and press on the gas simultaneously, “like two ships passing in the night.” I still think about that.

I got back behind the wheel of the Saab a few weeks later, but gave up for good when I got stuck on a hill and the car started leaking acrid-smelling smoke. After that, I always maintained that I could drive a stick if I absolutely had to, like if someone had a gun to my head and said they would let me live if I could shift to fifth gear and back. Luckily,  I never had to find out if I was right (I probably wasn’t).

Four years later while home for vacation I got another set of lessons from my mom, this time in her Saturn Astra. We drove around town and I only stalled at one light (though I stalled at that light at least eight times before I finally got the thing to start.) Then one day, my mom took my car to work and left me with the Astra, forcing me to either drive it or stay home all day, which is what she should have done all along, really, because that’s what finally did the trick.

title: 2013 Nissan Frontier
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Frontier earns a spot on shopping lists – for now.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Frontier
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Frontier
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Frontier--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Frontier here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Frontier is one of the top picks in a shrinking class of compact pickup trucks. But it shouldn’t rest on its laurels, since General Motors recently announced that a new GMC Canyon and Chevrolet Colorado are in the pipeline. The Frontier is a strong contender in the meantime, with good engine choices, including a 261-horsepower 4.0-liter V-6 and an optional 152-horsepower 2.5-liter inline four-cylinder engine for the base King Cab 4x2 model. A five-speed manual transmission is standard on four-cylinder models, along with an optional five-speed automatic transmission or six-speed manual transmission for the rest of the lineup. The two-wheel-drive Frontier with the four-cylinder engine and five-speed manual transmission returns good fuel economy at 19 mpg in city driving and 23 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA.  The Frontier has a maximum towing capacity of 6,500 pounds, making it a decent workhorse. Serious truckers can opt for four-wheel-drive models with a locking rear differential, tough Bilstein shock absorbers, and skid plates. The Frontier has a smooth ride and better driving dynamics than many of its rivals, but the cabin looks dated with its cheap trim. The Frontier offers plenty of truck for the money, with a fully boxed chassis, steel construction, and leaf-spring rear suspension. But it’s anybody’s guess what the Motor City has in store when it debuts its new midsize trucks.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Toyota Tacoma
2. Honda Ridgeline

New for 2013:
1. Nissan says details on the 2013 Frontier will be available at a later date. It goes in sale in early 2013.

title: 2013 Toyota Tundra
subTitle: However Texan it may be, the Tundra still trails among trucks.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Toyota Tundra
promoTeaser: 2013 Toyota Tundra
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Tundra--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Tundra here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Toyota has tried, and in many cases succeeded, in building the most popular cars in their respective classes. But not everything Toyota touches turns to gold, and the big, San Antonio-built Tundra is all you need for proof. Blessed as it is with Toyota’s legendary name and attendant reputation for quality, the Tundra almost overshoots the mark in terms of sheer bigness without necessarily matching the satisfying driving experience as, say, the new Ford F-150, or even the older, but more comfortable-in-their-own-skin, full-size pickups from Ram and Chevrolet/GMC. Oceans of hard plastic abound inside the Tundra, and particularly on two-door models, opening the doors can seem like moving a wall. The three available engines are strong, however, starting with a 270-horsepower V-6, 310-horsepower 4.6-liter V-8 and a 381-horsepower V-8 on the upgrade list if one needs still more grunt. While the Tundra is offered in three cab styles, three comfort grades (SR5, Limited, and Platinum), and three bed lengths, it is not offered in the bewildering array of ways one can find at any of the established American brands, and nor is the Tundra offered with a diesel engine or a heavy-duty spec.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Nissan Titan
2. Dodge Ram
3. Ford F-150

Looks :
1. TRD Rock Warrior package: seventeen-inch wheels, color-keyed bumper/grille, fog lamps, exterior graphics, and black upholstery.
2. TRD Off-road package: skid plates, eighteen-inch wheels, and off-road suspension.
3. Glitzy wheels/billet grille/luxury-laden interior for Platinum grade.

Cool Tech items :
1. Display navigation system with Entune app suite four double cab and CrewMax models.
2. Driver and front outboard passenger knee airbags.
3. Standard solar energy-absorbing glass.

New for 2013:
1. Chrome appearance package with three wheel choices.
2. TRD Rock Warrior package now available on 4X4 Limited (previously base model only).

title: Appearance: Black Is the New Black
subTitle: From a little trim to a complete monochromatic treatment, black is everywhere on cars now.
promoTitle: Appearance: Black Is the New Black
promoTeaserSmall: From a little trim to a complete monochromatic treatment, black is everywhere on cars now.
promoTeaser: From a little trim to a complete monochromatic treatment, black is everywhere on cars now.
metaTitle: Black Is the New Black -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Black is the new black when it comes to automotive exteriors and trim these days. Read about it as a style statement on cars in JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There are drivers who want a car that can take them to work and back every day without breaking down, and then there are drivers who want a car that does that and is also exciting, distinctive, and fun to drive. As Ford design manager Melvin Betancourt puts it: “Everyone wants their ride to represent them.” Luckily for the second group, customization of cars is becoming easier, with automakers providing more and more options for choosy buyers. One of the latest trends–black accessories and paint jobs–might already seem like an old standby, but that doesn’t mean it’s boring.

Ford offers black wheels on seven models, including family vehicles like the Edge Sport and Flex. On the Flex, the black wheels are part of the $1,495 Titanium appearance package, perhaps best enjoyed when paired with that car’s optional black roof. Subaru offers dark wheels for its Impreza, and Crosstrek models, and the Dodge Dart Rallye also comes with black wheels, only $395 in that model. Of course, if you don’t want to buy a new car just for a slight style upgrade, you can always buy your rims online. Prices range from a couple of hundred dollars to a couple of thousand dollars for a set.
Ford says that the Flex’s black wheels have been growing in popularity. One example is car-crazy Los Angeles, where there is a 50 percent "take rate" for them.

Wheels aren’t the only part of the car that looks better in black. Jeep and BMW have both done black-themed special editions of vehicles. Jeep’s limited edition 2012 Patriot Altitude sports black paint, black wheels, and a black interior. BMW built twenty 2011 Frozen Black Edition M3 coupes that also wore black paint, black wheels, and a black interior–although they also featured eye-catching blue-and-red contrast stitching. Those ultra-limited-run cars were so coveted that they sold out in twenty-two minutes, according to BMW.

Land Rover’s new special edition Evoque, with Victoria Beckham as design consultant, features glossy black wheels and exterior accents as well as a dark interior touched with the edition’s signature rose gold. That Evoque is also a very limited run, with only 200 to be manufactured worldwide.

The black theme is perhaps most common among sports cars. In 2012, Porsche sold black editions of the Boxster S and 911. Mercedes-Benz has been widely reported to be testing an SLS AMG Black Edition. And then, of course, there’s the Batmobile, perhaps a mythical inspiration for all the sinister and shadowy limited editions. These real cars may not be able to fly, but they’ll certainly turn heads.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you’ve gotten behind the wheel of a Ford Focus recently, you may have noticed that the windshield wipers aren’t your grandfather’s squeegees. Or you might not have noticed, since they’re not exactly the first things you look at in a new car.

But notice them or not, good wipers are crucial to your safety in poor weather conditions, and the Focus has innovative ones. Instead of the long, bulky motor that typically operates the two windshield wipers and runs the length of a car’s hood, the Focus employs two small, side-mounted motors. Not only do they weigh less and take up less space, they also improve the functionality of the wipers and allow them to operate independently.

The independent movements allow the blades to correct themselves if they become cockeyed during cleaning or operation. It also allows their resting positions to change periodically to prevent a problem called permanent set, a result of the hardening of rubber over time that can significantly decrease the life of a set of wiper blades.
As a bonus, developer Robert Bosch LLC says the smaller, lighter motors can lead to modestly reduced emissions and fuel consumption.

The direct drive windshield wipers were provided by Robert Bosch LLC for the Focus starting with the 2012 model, and similar technology from supplier Valeo is on Ford’s all-new 2013 Escape, Fusion, and C-Max. Best of all, the futuristic wipers come standard on all four models.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.
